words.def: Aluminium Alloy 6061 (not subject to sustained load cracking).[1] Currently (2012) used for manufacture of new diving cylinders.
words.name: AA6061

words.def: Aluminium Alloy 6351. This alloy is subject to sustained load cracking and requires periodical eddy current testing.[1] No longer used for new cylinder manufacture, but many cylinders of this alloy are still in service.
words.name: AA6351

words.def: see adjustable buoyancy life jacket
words.name: ABLJ

words.def:
Further information: Pressure measurement § Absolute, gauge and differential pressures - zero reference
Total static pressure at the reference point: Pressure relative to vacuum.
words.name: absolute pressure

words.def: see yoke fitting/valve.
words.name: A-clamp fitting/valve

words.def: see yoke adaptor
words.name: A-clamp adaptor

words.def:
see also Rebreather#Active addition semi-closed circuit
System for semi-closed circuit rebreather feed gas addition in which gas is added to the breathing circuit by a mechanism, regardless of current volume, and excess gas is vented to keep the loop volume within limits. Compare with passive addition
words.name: active addition

words.def:
Main article: Activated carbon
A filter medium used to remove oil, water and odours from breathing air.
words.name: activated charcoal

words.def: Australian Diver Accreditation Scheme: An international commercial and occupational diver certification scheme.
words.name: ADAS

words.def:
Also known as ABLJ or horse collar buoyancy compensator
A combination of buoyancy compensator and inflatable life jacket worn on the chest and round the neck.[2]
words.name: adjustable buoyancy life jacket

words.def: Automatic Diluent Valve: A demand valve set into the breathing loop of a rebreather to inject diluent gas into the loop when the loop volume falls and there is not enough gas for inhalation.
words.name: ADV

words.def:
Part of Launch and Recovery System
Gantry or davit for launching and recovering bells, stages or large ROVs.[3] Usually deployed by hydraulic rams which swing the frame over the deck or overboard as required. The load is hoisted and lowered by cables from the top of the frame.
words.name: A-frame

words.def: see arterial gas embolism
words.name: AGE

words.def: Decompression profile tending to shorter overall decompression time for a given pre-ascent dive profile, accepting increased risk of decompression sickness to reduce the overall ascent time.[4]
words.name: aggressive (decompression)

words.def: A section of cave which traps air or other gas at the top. This gas is not directly connected to the surface.[5]
words.name: air dome

words.def:
Main article: Airlift (dredging device)
A device based on a pipe, used in by divers to suck small objects, sand and mud from the sea bed and to transport the resulting debris upwards and away from its source. Air is injected into the lower end of the pipe and the rising bubbles entrain water and cause an upward flow which draws the material from the bottom along.
words.name: airlift

words.def: 1.  Completing a planned breathing gas mix by topping up with compressed air.[6]
words.name: air top

words.def:
Main article: Algal bloom
A rapid increase or accumulation in the population of algae (typically microscopic) in an aquatic system. Some blooms may be recognized by discoloration of the water resulting from the high density of pigmented cells. Visibility can be severely impaired over a period of hours to days.
words.name: algal bloom

words.def:
Main article: Alternative air source
A secondary supply of air or other breathing gas used by the diver in an emergency
words.name: alternative air source

words.def:
Main article: Alternobaric vertigo
Dizziness caused by a difference of pressure between the middle ears.
words.name: alternobaric vertigo

words.def:
Main article: Altitude diving
Diving at a location where the water surface is at an altitude which requires modification of decompression schedules.[7] (more than about 300 m (980 ft) above sea level.
words.name: altitude diving

words.def:
Main article: Ambient pressure
Pressure of the surroundings.
words.name: ambient pressure

words.def:
Main article: Hypoxia (medical)
Completely lacking in oxygen.
words.name: anoxia

words.def:
Main article: Aphasia
An impairment of language ability which may range from having difficulty remembering words to being completely unable to speak, read, or write
words.name: aphasia

words.def: 1.  Suspension of breathing, breath-hold.
words.name: apnea

words.def:
Main article: Aqua-lung
Self contained open circuit underwater breathing equipment consisting of a diving cylinder and diving regulator.
words.name: Aqua-lung

words.def:
Further information: History of decompression research and development § The arterial bubble decompression model
Decompression model in which the filtering capacity of the lung is assumed to have a threshold radius of the size of a red blood cell and sufficiently small decompression bubbles can pass to the arterial side, especially during the initial phase of ascent.
words.name: arterial bubble model

words.def:
Main article: Arterial gas embolism
Blockage of an artery by a gas bubble. A possible consequence of lung overpressure injury.
words.name: arterial gas embolism

words.def: A waistcoat (vest) style harness of heavy cloth with strong adjustable webbing straps so that the diver can not slide out under any predictable circumstance.[8]
words.name: AR vest

words.def: Part of the dive profile where the diver is moving upwards towards the surface. An ascent may be interrupted by stops (q.v.), when the diver maintains a functionally constant depth for the purpose of decompression, and pulls (q.v.), during which periods there is consistently upwards movement (minor variations in the scale of a few seconds are generally ignored).
words.name: ascent

words.def:
Further information: Decompression practice § Ascent rate
The rate at which depth is reduced at the end of a dive. An important component of decompression.
words.name: ascent rate

words.def:
Also ata or atmospheres absolute
Unit of absolute pressure equivalent to standard atmospheric pressure.
words.name: ATA

words.def:
Also ADS
Main article: Atmospheric diving suit
A small one-man articulated submersible of anthropomorphic form which resembles a suit of armour, with elaborate pressure joints to allow articulation while maintaining an internal pressure of one atmosphere.
words.name: atmospheric diving suit

words.def: see combat swimmer
words.name: attack swimmer

words.def: EN 14153-2 / ISO 24801-2 standard competence for recreational scuba diver. The level 2 "Autonomous diver" has sufficient knowledge, skill and experience to make dives, in open water, which do not require in-water decompression stops, to a recommended maximum depth of 20 m with other scuba divers of the same level, only when appropriate support is available at the surface, and under conditions that are equal or better than the conditions where they were trained without supervision of a scuba instructor, unless they have additional training or are accompanied by a dive leader.[9]
words.name: Autonomous diver

words.def: Breathing gas carried by a scuba diver in back mounted cylinders. Generally the primary breathing gas for the bottom or longest sector of a dive.[5]
words.name: back gas

words.def: A finning technique for moving backwards. Not an easy, powerful or elegant kick, but useful in many situations. The fins are angled outwards in opposite directions with the legs straight, then swept upwards and towards the diver by bending the knees in the power stroke. The knees may move downwards a bit at the same time by bending at the hips for stability. The return stroke feathers the fins by pointing them backwards in line with the body axis, to reduce forward thrust until the legs are straight again
words.name: backward kick

words.def: The practice of carrying a scuba set on the back of the diver, supported by a harness, backplate or stabilisor jacket BCD. Compare with sidemount
words.name: back mount

words.def:
Main article: Backplate and wing
A plate, normally made from metal, which rests against the diver’s back, and to which the primary scuba cylinders are attached. Held to the body by harness straps over the shoulders and round the waist. Sometimes also crotch straps and chest straps. Usually used with a back inflation buoyancy compensator.
words.name: backplate

words.def: A rigid or semi-rigid structure similar in function to a backplate, usually made of moulded plastic, but sometimes of metal, used either as a stiffener and reinforcement for a jacket style buoyancy compensator, or as the basis of a scuba harness independent of a buoyancy compensator. The backpack supports and stabilises the scuba cylinder on the diver's back.
words.name: backpack

words.def: Dive light carried as a spare to be used in case of failure of the primary light.[5]
words.name: backup light

words.def:
also secondary, safe second or octopus
A second regulator connected to a cylinder or manifolded twin set.[5]
words.name: backup regulator

words.def:
also back roll entry
Water entry method in which the seated diver rolls backwards off the side of the boat, allowing the scuba cylinders to strike the water first.
words.name: backward roll entry

words.def:
see also gas block, or gas switching block
A gas switching block specifically intended for connection of a bailout set to the main gas supply (which may be scuba or surface supply) which allows the diver to switch from main gas supply to emergency gas supply while continuously using the same mouthpiece, regulator second stage, full face mask or helmet. A bailout block is generally used on open circuit breathing apparatus, the equivalent function on a rebreather is provided by a bailout valve (BOV). The bailout block may be mounted on the side of a diving helmet or full-face mask, or may be mounted in a convenient place on the diver's harness, and includes a bailout valve, used to select the gas source, and one or more non-return valves to ensure that the emergency gas supply is directed only to the diver.
words.name: bailout block

words.def:
Main article: Bailout cylinder
A scuba cylinder carried by an underwater diver for use as an emergency supply of breathing gas in the event of a primary gas supply failure.
words.name: bailout cylinder

words.def: 1.  An open circuit demand valve built into a rebreather mouthpiece, or other part of the breathing loop, which can be isolated while the diver is using the rebreather to recycle breathing gas, and opened at the same time as isolating the breathing loop when the diver bails out to open circuit.
words.name: bailout valve

words.def:
Main article: Bailout cylinder
An independent breathing gas supply carried by a diver for use in case of failure of the main gas supply. Usually consists of a bailout cylinder with a first stage regulator, and either a second stage regulator or connected to a bailout block or bailout valve (q.v.) A submersible pressure gauge is also usually provided.
words.name: bailout set

words.def: Regulator designed to provide a consistent demand effort not affected by cylinder gas pressure or depth.[5]
words.name: balanced regulator

words.def:
Further information: Surface-supplied diving § Band mask
A heavy duty full-face mask with many of the characteristics of a lightweight demand helmet. In structure it is the front section of a lightweight helmet from above the faceplate to below the demand valve and exhaust ports, including the bailout block and communications connections on the sides. This rigid frame is attached to a neoprene hood by a metal clamping band, hence the name.
words.name: band mask

words.def: see cylinder bands
words.name: bands

words.def:
see also bar (unit)
Metric unit of pressure commonly used in diving, equal to 100 kiloPascal, and nearly equal to standard atmospheric pressure.
words.name: bar

words.def:
Main article: Barotrauma
Injury caused by pressure difference.
words.name: barotrauma

words.def: 1.  (also tank factor) Numeric value computed for a cylinder or manifolded set that relates volume and pressure in the imperial system of units. Computed by dividing nominal capacity (cubic feet) by cylinder working pressure (psi) to express cubic feet of volume per psi of fill pressure (sometimes multiplied by 100 to give cubic feet per 100 psi). Used to convert cylinder pressure to free gas volume.[5]
words.name: baseline

words.def: see diving stage
words.name: basket

words.def: Buoyancy And Trim wing. A back mounted buoyancy compensator cell used with sidemount harness. The buoyancy volume is mostly over the lower back.[10]
words.name: BAT wing

words.def: see buoyancy compensator
words.name: BCD

words.def: Uncontrolled buoyant ascent caused by inability to release gas from the buoyancy compensator faster than it expands due to pressure reduction of ascent.
words.name: BCD blowup

words.def:
see also dive marshal
A person on the beach who records when divers enter and exit the water. Typically used during recreational scuba training to keep track of the students, watch the gear, and provide assistance when required.
words.name: beach master

words.def: 1.  diving bell (q.v.)
words.name: bell

words.def: Mechanism or structure for guiding and constraining the motion of a bell when in the close vicinity of the deployment platform to improve handling in bad weather.[3]
words.name: bell cursor

words.def: A safety harness made of strong webbing, which is fastened around a diver over the exposure suit, and allows the diver to be lifted without risk of falling out of the harness.[11]
words.name: bell harness

words.def: Standby diver in the diving bell[3]
words.name: bellman

words.def: The part of a bell dive operation from bell lock-off to bell lock-on (to and from the life support system)[3]
words.name: bell run

words.def:
Further information: Umbilical cable § Diver
The combined supply and return hoses and cables for life-support, power and communications between a diving bell and the support platform
words.name: bell umbilical

words.def:
also belt slider, triglide, weight stop, weight slider
Hardware item with two parallel slots which is fitted to harness or weightbelt webbing to prevent other components such as D-rings and weights from sliding along the webbing.[5]
words.name: belt slide

words.def: A D-ring which has been bent about 45° near the straight section on both sides, forcing it to project slightly from the harness when pushed to one side, allowing easier attachment of clips.
words.name: bent D-ring

words.def: Decompression sickness: Injury caused by bubble formation in the body tissues after hyperbaric exposure.
words.name: bends

words.def: Built in breathing system. A demand breathing gas supply system with external exhaust used to provide chamber occupants with breathing gases other than the gas used to pressurise the chamber. Used for treatment gases and emergency breathing gas if the chamber is contaminated.[7]
words.name: BIBS

words.def: Three D rings welded together along their straight sides so that one is perpendicular to the other two. This uses the two flat rings to maintain the third in an upright position when mounted on harness webbing, allowing it to be more easily accessed to clip on stage cylinders. Named after Captain Billy Deans.[5]
words.name: Billy ring

words.def:
also B.K. hook or BK safety hook
A type of safety lifting hook which is held closed when under load by a lever system where the weight of the load holds the bill of the hook against the safety latch.[12]
words.name: BK hook

words.def: Mixing tube in which gases are continuously mixed prior to intake by a compressor, usually at atmospheric pressure.[6] Usually refers to manufacture of nitrox from air with added oxygen, but also used for trimix. Gas mixture is usually continuously analysed at the exit of the blending stick to monitor composition.
words.name: blending stick

words.def: Passing through a cave from one entrance to a different exit which the diver has not used before.[5]
words.name: blind traverse

words.def: Screw-in adaptor fitting which is fitted to a 200/240 bar DIN pillar valve to allow connection of a yoke regulator or filling whip.
words.name: block adaptor

words.def: Procedure of pressurising a diving chamber or saturation habitat.
words.name: blowdown

words.def:
Main article: Blowout (well drilling)
Uncontrolled release of crude oil and/or natural gas from a well after pressure control systems have failed.
words.name: blowout

words.def:
also BOP
Main article: Blowout preventer
A large, specialized valve used to seal, control and monitor oil and gas wells. Generally operated remotely by hydraulic ram.
words.name: blowout preventer

words.def:
Main article: Blue hole
A sink hole in a lake or the sea that is often the entrance to a cave. Blue holes in the sea are subject to tides so that their flows regularly reverse.[5]
words.name: blue hole

words.def:
also piston bolt
A metal connecter comprising a hook with a spring-loaded axial sliding rod which must be manually retracted to allow the hook to be clipped onto something or removed. May be single- or double-ended, and if single-ended is usually fitted with a swivel ring opposite the jaws.
words.name: bolt snap

words.def: Commercial diver slang for high pressure gas storage cylinder of around 50 litres water capacity, also known as a J.
words.name: bomb

words.def:
see bungee wing
Derogatory term for bungee wing based on fetishist terminology
words.name: bondage wing

words.def:
also booster pump
see also compressor
Main article: Booster pump
Machine used to increase pressure of a gas. Usually refers to the case where inlet pressure is above ambient pressure already.
words.name: booster

words.def: Blowout preventer stack: An assembly of several blowout preventer rams which may be used to shut off a well.
words.name: BOP stack

words.def: The gas breathed by the diver at the deepest part of the dive. Compare with travel gas and decompression gas.
words.name: bottom gas

words.def: Time used in calculating decompression obligation from decompression tables. For most tables this is defined as the elapsed time from starting the descent to starting the final ascent to the surface, excluding ascent and decompression time.
words.name: bottom time

words.def: Device used to measure and record the total time spent underwater during a dive. They do not generally only record bottom time {q.v.}.
words.name: bottom timer

words.def: 1.  also surface oriented dive: In commercial diving, bounce diving is the alternative to saturation diving. Any dive where the diver is decompressed directly after the dive.
words.name: bounce dive

words.def: see bailout valve
words.name: BOV

words.def:
Main article: Bowline
Knot used to form a secure, non-slipping loop at the end of a line.
words.name: bowline

words.def:
Main article: Boyle's law
Relationship between pressure and volume at constant temperature in an ideal gas.
words.name: Boyle's law

words.def: An area in a cave where a large amount of material has fallen from the overhead.[5]
words.name: breakdown room

words.def:
Main article: Breathing gas
Gas supplied to the diver to breathe, either directly to the diver or to the hyperbaric environment of the diving bell, dive chamber or saturation habitat.
words.name: breathing gas

words.def: The gas flow path in a rebreather comprising the diver's lungs, the mouthpiece, valves, hoses, counterlungs and scrubber through which gas is rebreathed.
words.name: breathing loop

words.def: A type of thermal lance initiated by an electric arc, in common use for underwater cutting work.
words.name: Broco cutter

words.def: Baited Remote Underwater Video. A system for assessing fish populations using video cameras to record fish attracted to a bait canister.
words.name: BRUV

words.def:
Further information: Ear clearing § Methods
Béance tubaire volontaire: Voluntary opening of the Eustachian tubes to equalise the middle ear.
words.name: BTV

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § Bubble models
Decompression models based on the assumption that bubbles will form during non-symptomatic decompression.
words.name: bubble models

words.def: Bailout cylinder carried by a scuba diver, particularly when diving solo.[5]
words.name: buddy bottle

words.def: Sharing breathing gas from one demand valve by two or more divers, generally after an out-of-gas emergency.
words.name: buddy breathing

words.def:
Main article: Buddy check
A procedure carried out by scuba divers using the buddy system where each diver checks that the other's diving equipment is configured, fitted, and functioning correctly just before entering the water to dive.
words.name: buddy check

words.def:
Main article: Buddy diving
A safety procedure where two or three divers monitor each other constantly during a dive and provide assistance or rescue when needed.
words.name: buddy diving

words.def: A short line between two divers, used to maintain contact during a dive, generally in poor visibility, or other conditions where the divers might become separated and not be able to quickly locate each other.
words.name: buddy line

words.def:
Main article: Buddy diving
A procedure where two divers look out for the safety of each other, and give assistance if the other gets into difficulty.
words.name: buddy system

words.def:
Main article: Bühlmann decompression algorithm
Diving tables and decompression algorithm on which the tables are based, and some dive computers are programmed, based on the dissolved gas decompression model derived and tested by Dr A.A. Bühlmann.
words.name: Bühlmann algorithm

words.def:
see also ring bungee
Length of shock cord used to restrain the top end of side mount cylinders and keep them tucked in at the diver's shoulder while swimming.[10] Usually clipped to the shoulder D-ring(s) of the harness and looped around the cylinder valve. May be attached to the back of the harness between the shoulder blades, or run continuous from one shoulder D-ring, around the back under the arms to the other shoulder D-ring.
words.name: bungee (sidemount)

words.def: Back inflation buoyancy compensator with shock cord lacing or loops which exert a force on the bladder to oppose expansion during inflation.
words.name: bungee wing

words.def: 1.  (Main article: Buoyancy). Upward force on an object immersed in a fluid due to pressure exerted over the immersed surface.
words.name: buoyancy

words.def: Procedure to test and adjust weights carried by an underwater diver. The diver wears all the personal equipment to be used for the planned dive, with the scuba tank(s) nearly empty, and the buoyancy compensator empty, in shallow water of the same density as expected on the dive, and adds or removes weights until neutrally buoyant. After the buoyancy check it is usual to distribute the weights for safety, trim and convenience.
words.name: buoyancy check

words.def:
also BC, BCD, buoyancy compensator device, ABLJ, horse collar, stabilisor jacket, stab jacket or wing
Main article: Buoyancy compensator (diving)
An airtight bladder worn by a diver which can be filled with air and vented to adjust and control the buoyancy of the diver.
words.name: buoyancy compensator

words.def: The skill of maintaining the appropriate buoyancy at any time during a dive.
words.name: buoyancy control

words.def: Device for measuring the actual capacity of a battery relative to its nominal capacity, and the associated functional time for the device that the battery is powering.[5]
words.name: burn tester

words.def: The effective use time of a battery powered device. Mainly used in reference to dive lights and scooters.[5]
words.name: burn time

words.def:
Main article: Rupture disk
A non-reclosing pressure relief device used to protect a diving cylinder from overpressurization.
words.name: burst disk

words.def: A type of bolt snap with a tapered guide gate opening formed by a protrusion on both the piston and the fixed sides of the gate.[5]
words.name: butterfly clip

words.def: A plate with two D-shaped cutouts on opposite sides of two to four parallel longitudinal slots for webbing. Used at the top back of the crotch strap in place of a butt-plate (q.v.) on minimalist sidemount harnesses.[10]
words.name: butterfly D-ring

words.def: A rigid or fairly stiff flexible lower extension to a backplate or other scuba harness supporting butt-plate rails, used for clipping off the lower end of sidemount cylinders to the harness.[10]
words.name: butt-plate

words.def: Diving in a cage designed to protect the diver from potentially aggressive large marine animals, usually sharks
words.name: cage diving

words.def: Catenary anchor leg mooring. Named for the catenary curve of the anchor cables that hold the buoy in position. Also referred to as single buoy mooring, monobuoy or loading buoy.[3]
words.name: CALM

words.def: A strap, usually of webbing, with a cam action tensioner buckle generally used to secure a diving cylnder to a backplate, stabilisor jacket BCD or other form of diving harness.
words.name: cam band

words.def: A closed lifting bag, usually cylindrical in form.
words.name: camel

words.def: Dive light comprising a light head connected to a battery canister by a cable
words.name: canister light

words.def:
Main article: Canoe diving
Scuba diving from canoes, used when the dive site is beyond convenient swimming distances.
words.name: canoe diving

words.def:
Main article: Carbon dioxide poisoning
The toxic effects of carbon dioxide, due to incomplete elimination of carbon dioxide resulting from skip breathing, excessive work of breathing, scrubber failure in a rebreather system, or inadequate ventilation in a diving chamber or free flow helmet. Occasionally caused by contaminated gas supply.
words.name: carbon dioxide poisoning

words.def:
Main article: carbon monoxide poisoning
The toxic effects of carbon monoxide, usually due to contaminated breathing gas supply.
words.name: carbon monoxide poisoning

words.def:
Main article: Cardio-pulmonary resuscitation
An emergency procedure which is performed in an effort to manually preserve intact brain function until further measures are taken to restore spontaneous blood circulation and breathing in a person in cardiac arrest
words.name: cardio-pulmonary resuscitation

words.def:
see also critical pressure
Critical Air Supply, the amount of breathing air required to safely exit a penetration dive. When the air supply reaches this level the dive has reached a planned turning point.[5]
words.name: CAS

words.def:
Main article: Cascade storage system
Decanting from several storage cylinders in succession, generally using a procedure to maximise charge pressures. Often used in partial pressure gas blending.
words.name: cascade filling

words.def: A mixture of water and carbon dioxide absorbent caused by flooding the scrubber, and which may reach the diver's mouth through the breathing loop. The alkalinity depends on the absorbent used.
words.name: caustic cocktail

words.def: A naturally occurring cavity in bedrock, or an underwater passage not illuminated by natural daylight, large enough to be entered by a human. Statute 810.13 of the Florida legislature defines a cave as: any void, cavity, recess, or system of interconnecting passages which naturally occurs beneath the surface of the earth or within a cliff or ledge, including natural subsurface water and drainage systems but not including any mine, tunnel, aqueduct, or other manmade excavation, and which is large enough to permit a person to enter. The word "cave" includes any cavern, natural pit, or sinkhole which is an extension of an entrance to a cave.[5]
words.name: cave

words.def:
Main article: Line marker
Directional line markers which point the way to an exit.
words.name: cave arrow

words.def: Filling a scuba cylinder to a pressure significantly above the rated safe working pressure (charging pressure).[5] Illegal in some jurisdictions, and increases risk of catastrophic failure.
words.name: cave fill

words.def: 1.  see distance line
words.name: cave line

words.def:
Main article: Distance line
A reel specifically made for cave diving, used to lay and recover large lengths of cave line which is used as a guide line to find the exit or a permanent guide line.
words.name: cave reel

words.def: 1.  Two or more interconnected underground rooms or passages in bedrock, each large enough to be entered by a human.[5]
words.name: cavern

words.def: Visibility greater than 40 feet, Maximum penetration of 130 feet, Maximum depth of 70 feet, and always within the ambient sunlight area. No passing through restrictions.[5]
words.name: cavern dive

words.def: Plastic card issued to a diver by a certification agency as evidence of completed diver training and experience required for the level of certification.
words.name: C-card or certification card

words.def: Closed Circuit Rebreather: see also ECCR, MCCR.
words.name: CCR

words.def: Closed Circuit Underwater Breathing Apparatus. Military alternative term for CCR
words.name: CCUBA

words.def: Solid overhead or decompression restriction to a safe direct vertical ascent to the surface
words.name: ceiling

words.def:
Main article: Cenote
A sinkhole in Mexico. Generally with vertical overhanging walls or shafts with water that open into a cave system.[5]
words.name: cenote

words.def: Occasion when the situation diverges notably and usually uncontrollably from the plan, sometimes involving immediate hazard to life and limb, and often involving poor judgement.
words.name: charlie foxtrot

words.def: Ring or hook shaped components used for installing and recovering conventional mooring systems. The chaser is hooked around the chain and pulled in the direction of the ancor until it slides onto the anchor shank and is stopped by the crown. The chaser is then used to break the anchor out by pulling directly upwards.[3]
words.name: chain chaser

words.def: Person competent to operate a diving chamber
words.name: chamber operator

words.def: Pressure stamped on a container for a permanent gas to indicate the maximum gauge pressure (measured or corrected to 15°C) that may be applied at the time of filling.[13]
words.name: charging pressure

words.def:
Main article: Charles' law
Relation of volume to temperature at constant pressure of an ideal gas.
words.name: Charles' law

words.def: Sleeveless neoprene wetsuit vest with attached hood.[14][15]
words.name: chicken vest

words.def: A section of a cave that is vertical or near vertical and like a shaft.[5]
words.name: chimney

words.def: Connection between pipeline end manifold (PLEM) and single point mooring buoy (SPM) using two to four separate flexible underwater hose strings.[3]
words.name: Chinese lantern

words.def:
Further information: Side mount diving § Cylinders
A strap around the neck of a sidemount cylinder used to hold the bolt snap closer to the neck so that the head of the cylinder stays closer to the diver's armpit. The choker can be a small webbing strap with a sliding buckle for adjustment, so it can be tightened to bring the clip closer to the neck or slacked off while in use.
words.name: choker (sidemount)

words.def:
Further information: Decompression sickness § Classification
A symptom of decompression sickness manifested by shortness of breath, caused by a large number of venous gas bubbles in the lung capillaries which interfere with gas exchange.
words.name: chokes

words.def:
also tree
Main article: Christmas tree (oil well)
An assembly of valves, spools, and fittings installed on top of the wellhead and used primarily to control the flow, usually oil or gas, out of the well.[3]
words.name: Christmas tree

words.def: A boarding ladder which has a single central rail with rigid cantilevered rungs to each side, allowing use while wearing swimfins.[16]
words.name: Christmas tree ladder

words.def: Usually Christo-lube MCG111, an oxygen compatible lubricant suitable for use in breathing apparatus in oxygen service.[5]
words.name: Christo-lube

words.def: Cave dive route in which there is a one-way segment. The circuit can be simple or complex depending on the number of jumps involved.[5]
words.name: circuit

words.def: see inshore diving
words.name: civils

words.def:
also dry bell
Further information: Diving bell § Structure of a typical closed bell
A closed or dry bell is a pressure vessel for human occupation which is lowered into the sea to the workplace, equalised in pressure to the environment, and opened to allow the divers in and out. Divers may be decompressed in the bell or transferred under pressure to a hyperbaric chamber at the surface.
words.name: closed bell

words.def: A weight used to keep the guide wires of a diving bell aligned.
words.name: clump weight

words.def: A systematic set of professional standards or written guidelines and rules of procedures to be followed by members of a profession, trade, occupation or organization. A code of practice may be compiled and agreed on by members of a particular profession or written guidelines issued by an official body or a professional association to its members to help them comply with its ethical standards. A code of practice does not normally have the force of law, but is often required or compulsory practice for members of an organisation.
words.name: code of practice

words.def: Welder who is trained and qualified and assessed as competent for a specified type of welding under specified conditions.
words.name: coded welder

words.def: A signal from a diver in a team that requires a response from another diver. There are three: Are you OK, Hold, and Surface.[5]
words.name: command signal

words.def:
Main article: Commercial diving
Working under pressure: Occupational activity where gas is breathed at pressure in excess of atmospheric pressure, usually underwater.
words.name: commercial diving

words.def:
Main article: Combat swimmer
Person trained in scuba diving or swimming underwater in a military capacity which can include combat
words.name: combat swimmer

words.def:
Main article: Completion (oil and gas wells)
The process of making a well ready for production.
words.name: completion

words.def: Person who is able to perform a task or operation safely and according to required procedures. May require formal assessment or accreditation, or registration with government body.[13]
words.name: competent person

words.def: Air at a pressure greater than ambient.
words.name: compressed air

words.def: Foam neoprene that has been compressed to reduce volume. Used for dry suits which are less affected by depth induced buoyancy changes.
words.name: compressed neoprene

words.def:
Main article: Compression arthralgia
Pain in the joints caused by exposure to high ambient pressure at a relatively high rate of compression
words.name: compression arthralgia

words.def:
Main article: Gas compressor
Machine which pressurises gas. Generally intake gas is at ambient pressure, outlet gas at higher pressure. High pressure breathing air compressor output pressure is usually 200 to 330 bar.
words.name: compressor

words.def: Book or file containing records of compressor operation, filling of cylinders and maintenance records.
words.name: compressor log

words.def: Person who operates a compressor, either to fill cylinders, or to provide breathing air to surface supplied divers.
words.name: compressor operator

words.def: Water that is enclosed and bounded sufficiently for safe training purposes. Generally implies that conditions are not affected by geographic or weather conditions, and that divers can not get lost.[17]
words.name: confined water

words.def:
Main article: Condensation
Liquid resulting from phase change from gas due to cooling or pressure change.
words.name: condensate

words.def: Tunnel or passage in a cave system.[5]
words.name: conduit

words.def: Decompression profile tending to minimise risk of decompression sickness at the cost of more decompression time for a given pre-ascent dive profile.[4]
words.name: conservative (decompression)

words.def: see restriction
words.name: constriction

words.def: see submersible pressure gauge
words.name: contents gauge

words.def:
Further information: Decompression practice § Continuous decompression
Decompression without stops. Instead of a fairly rapid ascent rate to the first stop, followed by a period at static depth during the stop, the ascent is slower, but without officially stopping. Ascent rate may vary with depth, usually slowing as the depth reduces.
words.name: continuous decompression

words.def: Conditions (usually medical) that indicate that a person should not dive.
words.name: contra-indications to diving

words.def: The tissue compartment that dictates the ascent profile of a given dive because it is theoretically the highest risk compartment for DCS.[4]
words.name: control compartment

words.def:
Main article: Controlled buoyant lift
A rescue technique used by scuba divers to raise an incapacitated diver to the surface from depth.
words.name: controlled buoyant lift

words.def:
also CESA
Main article: Controlled emergency swimming ascent
Emergency technique for surfacing, usually when no breathable gas is available at depth.
words.name: controlled emergency swimming ascent

words.def:
Main article: Line marker
Personal non-directional line markers that mark specific locations, or the direction of one's own exit at line intersections.
words.name: cookie

words.def: see standard diving dress
words.name: copper hat or copper helmet

words.def:
Further information: Standard diving dress § Suit description
Breastplate for a copper helmet and some other heavy helmets, which clamps to the diving suit, and to which the helmet is clamped
words.name: corselet

words.def:
Further information: Rebreather § Counterlung
Flexible bag or bellows in a rebreather which compensates for the change in volume in the loop during breathing.
words.name: counterlung

words.def: see cardio-pulmonary resuscitation
words.name: CPR

words.def: Pressure required to open a valve. Often applied to the difference in pressure over the diaphragm of a demand valve required to open the valve to start flow. This may differ significantly from the pressure difference required to keep the valve open once flow has been initiated, and the pressure to keep the valve open may vary with flow rate.
words.name: cracking pressure

words.def: see CAS
words.name: critical air supply

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § Critical difference hypothesis
Hypothesis that bubble formation during decompression will not occur if a critical pressure difference between tissue gas tension and inspired gas partial pressure is not exceeded.
words.name: critical difference hypothesis

words.def:
Further information: Scuba gas planning § Critical pressures
Cylinder gas pressure which determines a safe limit to an underwater activity on scuba, such as start of ascent or turnaround during a penetration.
words.name: critical pressure

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § Critical ratio hypothesis
Hypothesis that bubble formation during decompression will not occur if a critical ratio of tissue gas tension and inspired gas partial pressure for a given gas is not exceeded.
words.name: critical ratio hypothesis

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § The critical volume approach
Hypothesis that symptoms of decompression sickness will not be evident if a critical volume of tissue gas bubbles is not exceeded.
words.name: critical volume hypothesis

words.def: Harness strap that passes from the lower part of the harness at the back, through between the diver's legs, to the front of the harness, effectively securing the harness from sliding up along the torso. In safety harness this is often in two parts and allows the diver to be lifted by the harness without risk of falling out.[5]
words.name: crotch strap

words.def: Proprietary material for dry suits manufactured by DUI in a process where the foam neoprene suit material is degassed by exposure to high hydrostatic pressure to reduce the volume after assembly. Less buoyancy variation with depth as the material is less compressible after the treatment.[18]
words.name: crushed neoprene

words.def: Dump valve mounted on a drysuit cuff, usually relatively small and non-adjustable.
words.name: cuff dump

words.def:
Main article: Diphenyl oxalate
Trademark name Cyalume is a solid ester whose oxidation products are responsible for the chemiluminescence in a glowstick.
words.name: cyalume

words.def:
Main article: Cyanosis
The appearance of a blue or purple coloration of the skin or mucous membranes due to the tissues near the skin surface being low on oxygen
words.name: cyanosis

words.def: 1.  Diving cylinder: Refillable compressed gas container of water capacity between 0,5 L and 150 L.[13]
words.name: cylinder

words.def:
Main article: Diving cylinder
Rubber or plastic cover for the base of a scuba cylinder to protect it from abrasion, and in the case of domed end cylinders, to allow it to stand upright.
words.name: cylinder boot

words.def:
Further information: Diving cylinder § The cylinder valve
Valve fitted to a compressed gas cylinder to control gas flow into and out of the cylinder. Also pillar valve.
words.name: cylinder valve

words.def: Gas law describing the relation of component pressures of gases in a mixture to the total pressure.[5]
words.name: Dalton's law

words.def: see Divers Alert Network
words.name: DAN

words.def: Derogatory. Any part of a diver's equipment that dangles in a position that might impact the bottom or get caught on the surroundings.[5]
words.name: dangly

words.def: Decompression Analysis and Computation Program: Decompression planning software by Bill Hamilton.[5]
words.name: DCAP

words.def:
Main article: DRDC Toronto
Defence and Civil Institute of Environmental Medicine (Toronto, Canada).
words.name: DCIEM

words.def:
Further information: History of decompression research and development § DCIEM model and tables
Decompression tables based on the Kidd-Stubbs model, developed and published by the Defence and Civil Institute of Environmental Medicine.
words.name: DCIEM tables

words.def: see decompression illness
words.name: DCI

words.def: Deck decompression chamber: A twin-lock hyperbaric chamber suitable for surface decompression and emergency recompression. Large enough to hold at least two occupants, one of them lying down.
words.name: DDC

words.def: see decompression sickness
words.name: DCS

words.def: A heavy weight used to control the rise of a lift bag after breakout, or to capsize it to prevent a runaway lift
words.name: dead man anchor

words.def: 1.  The volume of a breathing apparatus which holds exhaled air, which is subsequently inhaled directly. without passing through a scrubber to remove carbon dioxide and without oxygen addition.
words.name: dead space or dead volume

words.def:
Further information: Cascade filling system
Transfer gas between cylinders by differential pressure. No energy is input, flow will stop when pressures equalised.
words.name: decant

words.def:
Main article: Decompression (diving)
Reduction in ambient pressure experienced by the diver during the ascent at the end of a dive or hyperbaric exposure, and the process of allowing dissolved inert gases to be eliminated from the body tissues during this reduction in pressure.
words.name: decompression

words.def:
Further information: Decompression practice § Decompression algorithms
Specified step-by step procedures used to calculate the decompression stops needed for a given dive profile. The algorithm can be used to generate decompression schedules for a particular dive profile, decompression tables for more general use, or be implemented in dive computer software.
words.name: decompression algorithm

words.def: see DSMB
words.name: decompression buoy

words.def:
Further information: Diving chamber § Decompression chamber
Hyperbaric chamber used for decompressing divers and emergency therapeutic recompression.
words.name: decompression chamber

words.def:
Further information: Decompression practice § Accelerated decompression
Gas breathed during decompression with a composition designed to accelerate decompression, usually by an increased oxygen content.
words.name: decompression gas

words.def:
Main article: Decompression illness
Illness caused by decompression. Includes decompression sickness and arterial gas embolism due to lung overexpansion barotrauma.
words.name: decompression illness

words.def:
Further information: Decompression practice § Decompression schedule
A specific ascent rate and series of increasingly shallower decompression stops that a diver uses to allow inert gases to be eliminated from the body tissues during ascent after a specific hyperbaric exposure, to reduce the risk of decompression sickness.
words.name: decompression schedule

words.def:
Main article: Decompression sickness
also DCS, divers' disease, the bends or caisson disease
A condition arising from dissolved inert gases coming out of solution during decompression as bubbles in the tissues, organs and blood vessels of the body causing symptoms ranging from rashes to death.
words.name: decompression sickness

words.def:
Further information: Decompression practice § Decompression stops
A pause during the ascent phase of a dive that a diver spends at a constant relatively shallow depth to allow safe release of inert gases from the body tissues to avoid decompression sickness.
words.name: decompression stop

words.def:
Further information: Decompression practice § Decompression tables
Printed cards or booklets that allow divers to determine a decompression schedule for a particular dive profile and breathing gas.
words.name: decompression tables

words.def:
also decompression bar
Further information: Decompression practice § Decompression trapezes
A horizontal bar or bars suspended at the depth of intended decompression stops by buoys used to make decompression stops more comfortable and more secure and provide the divers' surface cover with a visual reference for the divers' position.
words.name: decompression trapeze

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § Thermodynamic model and deep stops
Decompression stops which are deeper than the deepest stops required by decompression algorithms using dissolved phase models.
words.name: deep stops

words.def:
Main article: deep water blackout
Loss of consciousness caused by cerebral hypoxia on ascending from a deep breath-hold dive, when the swimmer does not necessarily experience an urgent need to breathe.
words.name: deep water blackout

words.def:
Main article: Dehydration
A condition where the water content of the body is reduced.
words.name: dehydration

words.def: Diving helmet which provides gas supply flow only when the diver inhales.
words.name: demand helmet

words.def:
Further information: Diving regulator § Demand valve
Mechanism for providing the user with breathing gas flow only when required.
words.name: demand valve

words.def: A pressure gauge calibrated to measure depth as a function of ambient pressure.
words.name: depth gauge

words.def: The pressure of the compressed gas in a cylinder at a temperature other than the nominal temperature at which charging pressure is specified. Usually refers to pressure when fully charged at a variation in temperature.[13]
words.name: developed pressure

words.def: Differential Global Positioning System An enhancement to Global Positioning System that provides improved location accuracy. DGPS uses a network of fixed, ground-based reference stations to broadcast the difference between the positions indicated by the satellite systems and the known fixed positions.
words.name: DGPS

words.def:
Main article: Diamond Reef System
Diamond Reef System is a diving skills program that uses a set of standardized portable obstacles to train and evaluate buoyancy skills and educate scuba divers on how to interact with coral reefs.
words.name: Diamond Reef System

words.def:
Main article: Decompression theory § Diffusion limited tissues and the "Tissue slab", and series models
Decompression hypothesis that the uptake and elimination of inert gas is limited by diffusion rates in the tissues
words.name: diffusion limited

words.def:
also sometimes dil
Further information: Rebreather § Gas sources
Gas mixture used to dilute the oxygen in the loop of a closed circuit rebreather to a partial pressure suited to the depth.
words.name: diluent

words.def:
also DIN valve, DIN regulator, DIN thread
Usually refers to G5/8" x 14 tpi[19] parallel thread fittings used to connect a cylinder valve to a filling connection or regulator first stage. Available in 200 bar and 300 bar versions which should only be inter-connectable in safe combinations.
words.name: DIN fitting

words.def:
See also: Diving cylinder § Connection to the regulator
Screw in adaptor which can be used with many recent 200/240 bar DIN cylinder valves to allow connection of Yoke regulators or filling whips.
words.name: DIN plug

words.def:
also Doing It Right
A holistic approach to scuba diving, which encompasses several essential elements, including fundamental diving skills, teamwork, physical fitness, and the use of streamlined and minimalistic equipment configurations.
words.name: DIR

words.def:
also penetration line or guideline
Main article: Distance line
A line used by scuba divers as a means of returning to a safe starting point in conditions of low visibility, water currents or where pilotage is difficult.
words.name: distance line

words.def:
also decompression computer
Main article: Dive computer
A device used by a scuba diver to measure the time and depth of a dive so that a safe ascent profile can be calculated and displayed so that the diver can avoid decompression sickness.[20]
words.name: dive computer

words.def: Factor used in gas consumption estimates which allows for increased breathing rate due to conditions other than depth. Range from 1.1 for relaxed, stress free conditions to >3.0 for heavy work.[21]
words.name: dive factor

words.def:
Main article: Dive flag
Flag used to indicate that there are divers in the water. There are two versions: the international code letter flag 'Alpha', , and the red flag with white diagonal bar, .
words.name: dive flag

words.def: EN 14153-3 / ISO 24801-3 standard competence for recreational scuba diver. A level 3 "Dive Leader" has sufficient knowledge, skill and experience to plan, organise and conduct their dives and lead other recreational scuba divers in open water, to conduct any specialised recreational scuba diving activities for which they have received appropriate training, plan and execute emergency procedures appropriate for the diving environment and activities. If diving and environmental conditions are significantly different from those previously experienced, they require an appropriate orientation with regard to local environmental conditions, and must have appropriate specialised training and experience to lead on dives which have more demanding operational parameters.[22]
words.name: Dive Leader

words.def: Recreational/club diving equivalent of a diving supervisor. Person who organizes and plans a group dive outing for recreational divers, assesses risk, logs divers into and out of the water and is available at the site to manage incident response.[23]
words.name: dive marshall

words.def:
Main article: Divemaster
A professional level recreational diver who leads a group of less experienced or visiting divers underwater.
words.name: divemaster

words.def:
Main article: Dive profile
The variation of depth with elapsed time during a dive, often depicted as a graph.
words.name: dive profile

words.def: see decompression tables
words.name: dive tables

words.def: The total elapsed time spent underwater during a dive.
words.name: dive time

words.def: An automatically operated electronic timer which records the elapsed time from the start of a dive.
words.name: dive timer

words.def: Hyperbaric chamber connecting other component chambers of a saturation life support system which may be at different pressures.
words.name: diver transfer chamber

words.def:
also DAN
Main article: Divers Alert Network
A non-profit organization for assisting divers in need and medical research on recreational scuba diving safety.
words.name: Divers Alert Network

words.def:
also dive tender
Person who assists the working diver to prepare for a dive, get in and out of the water, and to undress from the diving equipment, and who tends the lifeline or umbilical while the diver is underwater.
words.name: diver's attendant

words.def:
Main article: Diving bell
A rigid chamber suspended from a cable and used to transport divers to depth and back to the surface.
words.name: diving bell

words.def: 1.  A simple form of submersible vessel to take divers underwater and to provide a temporary base and retrieval system in the depths (diving bell).
words.name: diving chamber

words.def: Legal persona responsible for commercial diving operations.
words.name: diving contractor

words.def:
see also overweighting
Practice of carrying significantly more ballast weight than necessary to neutralise buoyancy. Common in professional diving operations where the diver needs to remain in firm cintact with the bottom to work effectively, and is tethered by a lifeline or umbilical to a control point at a place of safety, which is managed by a tender.
words.name: diving heavy

words.def: see regulator
words.name: diving regulator

words.def:
Main article: Diving safety officer
The person who administers a United States university's research diving safety program.[24]
words.name: diving safety officer

words.def:
Main article: Diver communications
Hand sign and light sign system used by scuba divers to communicate when underwater.
words.name: diving signals

words.def:
also known as the basket
Further information: Decompression practice § Diving stages and wet bells
A platform on which a diver stands which is hoisted into the water, lowered to the workplace at the bottom, and then hoisted up again to return the diver to the surface and lift him out of the water.
words.name: diving stage

words.def: Person with overall responsibility for commercial diving operations at a large installation.[3]
words.name: diving superintendent

words.def:
Main article: Diving supervisor
Person in charge of, and responsible for safety of a commercial diving operation.
words.name: diving supervisor

words.def: Diving Medical Advisory Committee: An independent body of diving medical specialists from Northern Europe which provides advice about medical and certain safety aspects of commercial diving.[25]
words.name: DMAC

words.def: Diving medical technician: A paramedic specialising in diving related conditions.
words.name: DMT

words.def: A domed window of optical quality glass or plastic which covers the front of an underwater camera or video housing.
words.name: dome port

words.def: Slang term for the corrugated buoyancy compensator inflation and deflation hose.[5]
words.name: donkey dick

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § Doppler ultrasonic bubble detection
Ultrasonic signals reflected from bubble surfaces to identify and quantify gas bubbles present in venous blood.
words.name: Doppler bubble detection

words.def: (also line arrow). Triangular plastic line marker with two slots used to indicate the direction of the exit.[5]
words.name: Dorf arrow

words.def: In the direction of flow. Displaced from the reference point in the direction of flow
words.name: downstream

words.def:
See also: Diving regulator § Upstream vs downstream
Valve in which the closure is downstream of the orifice. Pressure in the line tends to assist in opening the valve. When spring-loaded a downstream valve may open automatically if the pressure difference is excessive, thus functioning as a pressure relief valve
words.name: downstream valve

words.def: Period when planned activities can not be done due to unforeseen or uncontrollable circumstances.[3]
words.name: down time

words.def: Status of the dynamic positioning system regarding positional accuracy and reliability. Green indicates normal operation, yellow indicates degraded operation and red indicates emergency.[3]
words.name: DP alert

words.def: Dynamic positioning footprint: The area around the nominal position to which a dynamically positioned vessel is constrained by the DP system.[3]
words.name: DP footprint

words.def: 1.  Diver propulsion vehicle.
words.name: DPV

words.def: A ring shaped like a capital D, usually of stainless steel, stitched or buckled to a diver's harness and used as an attachment point for lifeline, cylinders or other equipment.
words.name: D-ring

words.def: Indicator tube used for testing breathing gas quality.
words.name: Draeger tube

words.def:
Main article: drift diving
Any dive where the diver is transported significantly by drifting with currents during the dive.
words.name: drift diving

words.def: Ship built or converted for offshore well drilling, using dynamic positioning to maintain position in deep water.[3]
words.name: drillship

words.def: Weight used during descent and ascent, but left on the bottom at the guideline during the deep part of the dive when it is not needed due to suit compression.[5]
words.name: drop weight

words.def:
Main article: Drowning
The process of experiencing respiratory impairment from submersion/immersion in liquid.
words.name: drowning

words.def:
Main article: Dry bag
Bag which seals in a watertight manner. Used for keeping clothes and other equipment dry in a wet environment.
words.name: dry bag

words.def: see closed bell
words.name: dry bell

words.def:
Further information: Diving cylinder § Temperature change during filling
Filling scuba cylinders without the use of a water bath for cooling.[26]
words.name: dry filling

words.def:
Main article: Dry suit
A watertight suit worn to keep the diver dry and to provide protection from the environment. Thermal insulation may be provided by the suit or garments worn under the suit.
words.name: dry suit

words.def: 1.  Dive/Surface valve: Valve on the mouthpiece of a rebreather which can be switched between the loop and ambient air at the surface.
words.name: DSV

words.def:
also delayed surface marker buoy
An inflatable marker buoy deployed from underwater to indicate the position of a diver and to control ascent rate. Can also be used to mark a position or signal an emergency.
words.name: DSMB

words.def:
Main article: Duckbill valve
A non-return valve, manufactured from rubber or synthetic elastomer, and shaped somewhat like the beak of a duck. Used as exhaust valve in some twin-hose diving regulators
words.name: duckbill valve

words.def: Valve used to release excess air from a drysuit or buoyancy compensator.[5]
words.name: dump valve

words.def:
Main article: Dynamic positioning
Method of keeping a diving support platform in position without anchoring, using thrusters and positional feedback.
words.name: dynamic positioning

words.def:
Main article: Dysbarism
Medical conditions resulting from changes in ambient pressure.
words.name: dysbarism

words.def:
Main article: Equivalent air depth
Equivalent Air Depth. Depth at which partial pressure of nitrogen in a Nitrox mixture at a given depth is equal to the partial pressure of nitrogen in air. Used in decompression calculations.
words.name: EAD

words.def: Enriched Air Nitrox, see Nitrox
words.name: EAN

words.def: A mixture of alcohol and acetic acid in water used as a drying agent and disinfectant to rinse the ears after diving, to prevent ear infections.
words.name: ear beer

words.def:
Main article: Ear clearing
Equalising the pressure in the middle and external ear by opening the Eustachian tubes. Several techniques are used.
words.name: ear clearing

words.def: Electronic closed circuit rebreather. Sometime ECCCR for electronically controlled closed circuit rebreather.
words.name: ECCR

words.def: Method of non-destructive testing using electromagnetic induction to detect flaws in conductive materials. It is used to detect cracks in parallel neck threads of aluminium cylinders. Also called Visual Plus inspection. Required for cylinders of AA6351 alloy.
words.name: eddy current test

words.def: European Diving Technology Committee. The EDTC aims to make European professional diving safer.[27]
words.name: EDTC

words.def:
also Thalmann algorithm, (VVAL18)
Main article: Thalmann algorithm
Exponential-Linear algorithm of 2008 US Navy tables, assumes exponential ingassing and a combination of linear and exponential outgassing rates.
words.name: E-L algorithm

words.def: An electro-chemical fuel cell which produces a voltage proportional to the partial pressure of oxygen.
words.name: electro-galvanic oxygen sensor

words.def:
also emergency beacons or EPIRB,
Main article: Distress radiobeacon
Emergency position-indicating radio beacons are tracking transmitters which aid in the detection and location of boats and people in distress at sea.
words.name: emergency position indicating radio beacon

words.def:
also ESA, Controlled emergency swimming ascent, CESA
Emergency procedure where the diver makes an ascent from depth after a breathing gas supply failure.
words.name: emergency swimming ascent

words.def: Equivalent Nitrogen Depth or Equivalent Narcotic Depth. The depth at which the narcotic effects of nitrogen in a given Trimix mixture at a given depth are equivalent to the effects of air. Used to choose nitrogen content of a Trimix breathing gas for a planned dive profile.
words.name: END

words.def: see emergency position indicating radio beacon
words.name: EPIRB

words.def: Balance pressure of a gas filled space with the ambient pressure, by adding or venting gas, to prevent barotrauma or pressure damage.
words.name: equalise

words.def:
also EAD
Main article: Equivalent air depth
A way of approximating the decompression requirements of nitrox mixtures at depth by comparison with the depth at which air would require the same decopression.
words.name: equivalent air depth

words.def:
also END
Main article: Equivalent narcotic depth
A way of expressing the narcotic effect of a breathing gas mixture at depth by comparison with the depth at which air would have a similar effect.
words.name: equivalent narcotic depth

words.def: A dive in which the risk of decompresssion sickness, oxygen toxixity, and/or exposure to the elements is substantially greater than on a normal working dive.[28]
words.name: exceptional exposure

words.def:
Main article: Umbilical cable § Diver
The combined supply and return hoses and cables for life-line, life-support, power and communications between a diving bell and the diver
words.name: excursion umbilical

words.def:
also: ventilation/oxygen extraction ratio
Ratio between minute ventilation and oxygen uptake, the volume rate of gas breathed to the amount of oxygen taken up in the bloodstream. A typical surface extraction ratio of 20 would mean that for every 20 litres of gas breathed, 1 litre of oxygen would be absorbed in the lungs.
words.name: extraction ratio

words.def: Viewport of a full face mask or helmet
words.name: faceplate

words.def: Wet suit that covers the torso and legs only; it resembles a bib overall or salopettes.
words.name: farmer john

words.def:
Main article: Fatigue (material)
Cracking in a material resulting from multiple stress cycles below the ultimate or yield strength. Usually refers to large number of cycles.
words.name: fatigue cracking

words.def: Technique for emergency breathing from a free-flowing demabd valve where the diver manually controls air flow by opening and closing the cylinder valve.
words.name: feather breathing

words.def: see full-face mask
words.name: FFM

words.def: Feet fresh water. Unit of pressure equal to 1/34 atm. Not a linear measure of depth.
words.name: FFW

words.def:
Main article: Filtration
Process for removing impurities from a fluid. Particulates are commonly removed by passing the fluid through porous material with pore size small enough to trap the particles (e.g. micron filters). Liquids and gases are commonly absorbed or adsorbed by the surface of the filter medium (Activated carbon, Molecular sieve, Silica gel), or may be chemically combined with the medium (Sodalime) or catalytically converted (Hopcalite) into a less objectionable substance.
words.name: filtration

words.def: Elastic rubber straps used to help prevent fins from falling off the diver's feet.
words.name: fin keepers

words.def:
see Diving regulator#First stage
Diving regulator component which reduces gas pressure from stoage pressure in the cylinder to interstage pressure for supply to the second stage and for suit and BC inflation.
words.name: first stage

words.def: Synthetic elastomers (rubber) with good performance in high partial pressures of oxygen. Preferred material for o-rings in diving regulators for oxygen service.
words.name: fluorocarbon elastomers

words.def: Movement of water through a cave system. Similar in meaning to current in open water.[5]
words.name: flow

words.def: finning style where the fins are alternately moved up and down by movements of the full, usually fairly straight, leg.[5] Thrust is developed on both up and down strokes. See also modified flutter kick
words.name: flutter kick

words.def:
Main article: Anti-fog
Condensation of water vapour on the inside surface of a mask or helmet faceplate, reducing visibility.
words.name: fogging

words.def: Water entry technique used by scuba divers from a boat or platform too high or unsuitable for backward roll entry. The diver bends forward at the hips and waist and falls forward into the water, making a partial somersault and breaking the water with the cylinder, back and shoulders. Not suitable for heights more than about 2 m.
words.name: forward roll entry

words.def: Voice communications using separate wire pairs for each direction.
words.name: four-wire system

words.def: Tramsportable assemblies of gas cylinders connected by a manifold and securely mounted to a structural framework.[3]
words.name: frame

words.def:
see also free gas
Air at normal atmospheric pressure
words.name: free air

words.def:
Main article: Free-diving
Underwater diving that does not involve the use of external breathing apparatus, but relies on a diver's ability to hold his or her breath until resurfacing. also Breath-hold diving, and apnea (q.v.).
words.name: free-diving

words.def: 1.  Constant flow rate air supply
words.name: free flow

words.def: A helmet where the breathing air supply is supplied at an approximately constant rate regardless of the diver's instantaneous breathing rate.
words.name: free flow helmet

words.def: Gas at normal atmospheric pressure. Usually refers to the volume of some amount of compressed gas when allowed to expand to atmospheric pressure at constant temperature
words.name: free gas

words.def: Equivalent volume of compressed gas if expanded to atmospheric pressure at constant temperature.[29]
words.name: free gas volume

words.def:
Main article: Ear clearing
Technique for equalising the middle ear by pinching the nose closed and moving the back of the tongue upwards.
words.name: Frenzel maneuver

words.def:
Main article: Frog kick
Finning technique where thrust is developed by sweeping the fins horizontally toward each other with the fins twisted into a nearly vertical plane, with the soles facing each other, followed by a recovery stroke which develops negligible thrust where the fin blades are feathered. The legs are fairly straight during the power stroke. See also modified frog kick
words.name: frog kick

words.def:
Main article: Frogman
A scuba diver, particularly a military diver on an undercover mission.
words.name: frogman

words.def: feet sea water: Unit of pressure equal to 1/33 atm. Not a linear measure of depth.
words.name: fsw

words.def: Voice communication system where both users can transmit and receive at the same time.
words.name: full duplex

words.def: Diving mask covering the eyes, nose and mouth, and provides the diver with breathing gas
words.name: full-face mask

words.def: The space between two cave guidelines. Usually between a main guideline and a branch line.
words.name: gap

words.def: A relatively short length of cave line on a spool used to bridge a gap between lines when making an excursion from the main guideline to a branch guideline.
words.name: gap spool

words.def: (also gator (US)) Textile legging wrapped around the calf and ankle area over a dry suit to restrict the amount of air that can get into the lower leg area. Also can reduce drag of the suit in this area by smoothing over creases and folds.
words.name: gaiter

words.def: 1.  Person who mixes breathing gases for diving, filling diving cylinders with gas mixes such as nitrox or trimix.
words.name: gas blender

words.def:
Main article: Gas blending
Mixing breathing gases for diving, filling diving cylinders with gas mixes such as nitrox or trimix.
words.name: gas blending

words.def:
Main article: Gas embolism
Blockage of blood vessel by a bubble of gas.
words.name: gas embolism

words.def: Contaminants in the compressed breathing air or gas mixture which are in gaseous form. Compare with particulate and condensate impurities.
words.name: gaseous impurities

words.def:
Main article: Gas composition
The fraction by molecular count, volume or pressure (they all come to the same thing) of a specific gas in a mixture of gases.
words.name: gas fraction

words.def:
Further information: Surface-supplied diving § Gas panel
The control equipment for providing breathing gas to surface supplied divers via umbilicals. Primary and reserve gas is supplied to the panel through shutoff valves from a low pressure compressor or high pressure storage cylinders.
words.name: gas panel

words.def: The depth during an ascent or decompression when the intake of dissolved gas is exceeded by outgassing.
words.name: gas reversal point

words.def: Operating mode for a personal dive computer where the decompression calculation is disabled, and the unit operated only as a timer and depth gauge. Typically used when diving with gas mixtures not supported by the algorithm, in which case decompression tables are used to monitor and control the decompression schedule.
words.name: gauge mode

words.def:
Main article: Pressure measurement § Absolute, gauge and differential pressures - zero reference
Gauge pressure is zero-referenced against ambient air pressure, so it is equal to absolute pressure minus atmospheric pressure
words.name: gauge pressure

words.def: A needle valve or small bore orifice between the pressure supply and the gauge which damps pressure fluctuations.
words.name: gauge snubber

words.def:
Main article: Gay-Lussac's law
Relation between temperature and pressure in an ideal gas for a constant volume.
words.name: Gay-Lussac's law

words.def: 1.  Relation between the variables pressure, volume and temperature for a given mass of a given mixture of an ideal gas.
words.name: general gas law

words.def: A single-use, translucent plastic tube containing isolated substances that, when combined, make light through chemiluminescence
words.name: glowstick

words.def: A general purpose adjective to denote particularly difficult section of cave, which may be low, tight, silty, etc. or a combination.[5]
words.name: gnarly

words.def: The convention in cave diving that anyone can turn the dive at any time for any reason.[5]
words.name: Golden rule

words.def: The permanent main guideline in a cave system, that usually starts well inside the cave. Often yellow or gold in colour.[5]
words.name: gold line

words.def: A handle used to carry the primary dive light head comprising a rigid slot through which the fingers and palm of the hand are extended, so that the light rests on the back of the hand, facing the direction of the extended fingers.
words.name: Goodman handle

words.def:
Main article: Global Positioning System
A satellite navigation system that provides location and time information in all weather, anywhere on or near the Earth, where there is an unobstructed line of sight to four or more GPS satellites
words.name: GPS

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § Gradient factors
A way of modifying the M-value of a decompression algorithm to a more conservative value. Often used to bias the algorithm towards deeper stops.
words.name: gradient factor

words.def: see distance line
words.name: guide line

words.def:
also Haldanean
Further information: Decompression theory § Critical ratio hypothesis
Decompression models based on the principles described by John Scott Haldane.
words.name: Haldanian

words.def: An alternative reserve calculation strategy to the rule of thirds for breathing stage cylinders. The cylinder is breathed down to half of its starting pressure plus 200 psi, so that a stage cylinder filled to 3000 psi would be breathed down to 1700 psi before being dropped.[5] This is a less conservative strategy for pressures greater than 1200psi.
words.name: half+200

words.def:
Main article: Half duplex
Voice communications system where users take turns to send and receive.
words.name: half duplex

words.def: Diver's mask which covers the eyes and nose but not the mouth.
words.name: half mask

words.def: see tissue half times
words.name: half times

words.def:
Main article: Halocline
A strong variation in salinity over a small depth range within a body of water. Often visible as a blurred or shimmering region due to uneven refractive index.
words.name: halocline

words.def: To remain stationary at a specific depth and location, particularly when decompressing.[5]
words.name: hang

words.def: Surface supplied diving, generally in professional diving, either wearing a modern diving helmet or the old-style standard diving dress and brass helmet.
words.name: hard hat diving

words.def: Voice communications using a cable for transmission.
words.name: hardwire communications

words.def: straps and webbing with associated buckles, D-rings and other accessories used to support the breathing apparatus and secure it to the diver. The harness often has other functions such as supporting weighting and buoyancy control systems and for recovery of the diver from the water.
words.name: harness

words.def: Commercial diver term for diving helmet.
words.name: hat

words.def: see standard diving dress
words.name: heavy gear

words.def:
Main article: Heliox
Mixtures of helium and oxygen for use as a breathing gas.[30]
words.name: heliox

words.def:
Main article: Heliair
Trimix blends made by topping up helium with air.
words.name: heliair

words.def: Manoeuver in which a (usually horizontally trimmed) diver uses small fin movements to rotate on the spot on a vertical axis.
words.name: helicopter turn

words.def:
Main article: Helium
An inert gas which is used as a component of breathing gas mixtures for deep diving.
words.name: helium

words.def:
Main article: Helium analyzer
An instrument used to identify the presence and concentration of helium in a mixture of gases
words.name: helium analyzer

words.def: see hard hat diving
words.name: helmet diving

words.def: Description of the relation between solubility of a given gas in a given liquid as pressure varies.
words.name: Henry's law

words.def: High intensity discharge light: Used in cave diving light heads (q.v.).
words.name: HID light

words.def: Hazard Identification and Risk Analysis: A risk management procedure for identifying hazards and assessing the risk associated with them and ways to reduce the risk to an acceptable level.
words.name: HIRA

words.def: High pressure, generally gas pressures in excess of 30 bar. In diving context gas working pressures do not frequently exceed 300bar, but pressures in hydraulic systems may be considerably higher.
words.name: HP

words.def: A scuba combination of backplate, wing, one-piece harness with crotch-strap, regulator arrangement including long-hose primary with a necklaced secondary demand valve, and, if used with twin cylinders, an isolation manifold. Named after Willian Hogarth Main, a developer and proponent of the system.
words.name: Hogarthian configuration

words.def: A scuba configuration where the primary demand valve has a long hose which is routed under the righr arm, usually tucked under a light battery canister on the waist belt of the harness, and around behind the neck to reach the mouth from the right hand side. Part of the Hogarthian configuration (q.v.).
words.name: Hog looped

words.def: Close-fitting thermal head protection, usually neoprene foam, but also latex on some dry suits.
words.name: hood

words.def:
also hooka and airline diving
Further information: Surface-supplied diving § Airline
Also known as airline diving; surface supplied diving where the breathing air is supplied to the diver by a simple hose. The diver usually breathes through a mouth held demand valve.
words.name: hookah

words.def:
Main article: Hopcalite
Catalyst sometimes used in air filters to oxidise carbon monoxide to carbon dioxide. Hopcalite is a mixture of manganese oxide, copper oxide and a small amount of silver oxide.
words.name: hopcalite

words.def: see adjustable buoyancy lifejacket
words.name: horse collar

words.def: breathing gas mixture with a high percentage of oxygen for the depth at which it is used. Using a gas mixture with a high partial pressure of oxygen.
words.name: hot mix

words.def:
Further information: Diving suit § Hot water suits
An insulated pipe in the umbilical line, which links the diver to the surface support, carries the hot water from a heater on the surface down to the suit. The diver controls the flow rate of the water allowing him to vary the warmth of the suit.
words.name: hot water suit

words.def:
Main article: HPNS
High-pressure nervous syndrome: A neurological and physiological diving disorder that results when a diver descends below about 500 feet (150 m) while breathing a helium–oxygen mixture.
words.name: HPNS

words.def: Health and Safety Executive (UK), Government department responsible for occupational diver safety in UK.
words.name: HSE

words.def:
Further information: Diving cylinder § Types of cylinder valve
Cylinder valve body with two outlets and two valve mechanisms which can be independently controlled so that two regulator first stages can be fitted. Similar to Y-valve but in configuration where the second valve is parallel to the primary, though the secondary valve can sometimes be swivelled.
words.name: H-valve

words.def:
Main article: Hydrostatic pressure
Pressure due to the weight of the water column above a point at depth.
words.name: hydrostatic pressure

words.def:
Main article: Hydrostatic test
Non-destructive test to revalidate pressure vessels which uses water as a test medium. The vessel is pressurised to the test pressure (q.v.) and measured for permanent set.
words.name: hydrostatic test

words.def:
Main article: Hydreliox
Deep diving breathing gas mixture of hydrogen, helium and oxygen.
words.name: hydreliox

words.def:
Main article: Hydrox
Deep diving breathing gas mixture of hydrogen and oxygen.
words.name: hydrox

words.def: A lifeboat with a hyperbaric chamber and life support system built into it for evacuating saturation divers in an emergency.
words.name: hyperbaric lifeboat

words.def: Additional filter to produce air of oxygen compatible quality. This may be built into the filling system or temporarily connected when required.
words.name: hyperfilter
