words.def:
Main article: Hypercapnia
Excessive level of carbon dioxide in the body.
words.name: hypercapnia

words.def: 1.  A deliberate deep breathing to reduce blood carbon dioxide level to extend the duration of a free dive.
words.name: hyperventilation

words.def:
Main article: Hypothermia
A lowering of deep body temperature due to heat loss.
words.name: hypothermia

words.def:
Main article: Hypoxia (medical)
Abnormally low tissue oxygen concentration: Insufficient oxygen in the body to support normal activities or consciousness.
words.name: hypoxia

words.def: Isobaric counterdiffusion: The diffusion of gases in opposite directions caused by a change in the composition of the external ambient gas or breathing gas without change in the ambient pressure.
words.name: ICD

words.def: International Diving Regulators Forum: A voluntary group of diving regulators and certifying agencies formed to work together toward mutual recognition and to identify and implement best practices in diver training with the object of harmonizing cross border diver training standards outside Europe. Members include Australia, Canada, France, Norway, South Africa and United Kingdom.[31]
words.name: IDRF

words.def: International Diving Schools Association: Formed with the primary purpose of developing common internationional diving standards for all occupational divers, Offshore, Inshore and Inland, and specialist related non-diving qualifications e.g. Supervisor, DMT and LST.[32]
words.name: IDSA

words.def: International Marine Contractors Association.
words.name: IMCA

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § Inert gas uptake (Ingassing)
A gas which is not metabolically active, used to dilute the breathing gas.
words.name: inert gas

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § Inert gas uptake (Ingassing)
Inert gas uptake in body tissues during a dive or other hyperbaric exposure.
words.name: ingassing

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § Inherent unsaturation
Metabolic reduction of total gas pressure in the tissues.
words.name: inherent unsaturation

words.def: Colloquial term for a diver who works on inland dive sites or coastal waters not associated with the oil and gas industry. also referred to as "civils" as much of this work is connected with civil engineering works.[3]
words.name: inshore diver

words.def: The state of the internal surface of a cylinder regarding corrosion, contamination and cracking.
words.name: internal condition of cylinder

words.def: Gas trapped in the spaces between organs after lung barotrauma.
words.name: interstitial emphysema

words.def: Intermediate Pressure, or Interstage Pressure. The reduced pressure between the first and second stages of a diving regulator. Also referred to as LP (Low Pressure) in this context.
words.name: IP

words.def: Connection between two scuba cylinders which when open allows free flow of gas in both directions between the cylinders, but has an isolation valve to block this flow.
words.name: isolation manifold

words.def: 1.  valve in an isolation manifold (q.v.) used to close the gas passage through the manifold and isolate the contents of the two cylinders. Used to prevent a leak on one cylinder from causing the other cylinder to also lose gas.
words.name: isolation valve

words.def: A line secured at both ends to serve as a support[33] or guide.
words.name: jackstay

words.def:
Main article: Jackup rig
A type of mobile platform that consists of a buoyant hull fitted with a number of movable legs, capable of raising its hull over the surface of sea. The buoyant hull enables transportation of the unit and all attached machinery to a desired location. Once on location the hull is raised to the required elevation above the sea surface on its legs supported by the sea bed.
words.name: Jack-up rig

words.def: Bulk gas storage cylinder with internal volume 50 litres.
words.name: J-cylinder

words.def: see upline
words.name: Jersey upline

words.def:
Main article: JIC fitting
A type of pipe and hose fitting with a 37-degree flare seating surface. Commonly used in umbilical hose connections.
words.name: JIC fitting

words.def:
Main article: JIM suit
An atmospheric diving suit manufactured by Underwater Marine Equipment Limited.
words.name: JIM suit

words.def: webbing strap system used with diving helmets to hold the helmet assembly down on the diver to prevent buoyancy lifting it when underwater.
words.name: jocking strap

words.def:
Main article: Jonline
A short line used to connect to a shotline or anchor line, allowing the diver to move a short horizontal distance away to decompress. The line helps compensate for vertical movement in the anchor line or shot line due to waves.
words.name: Jonline

words.def: A path from a main guideline to another which is not in contact
words.name: jump

words.def: A camera mounted on a frame, which when lowered to the bottom of a body of water, takes a photograph, usually of the bottom under the camera. The frame constrains the camera to a fixed camera to subject distance, resulting in photographs of uniformly sized areas of bottom, equivalent to quadrats.
words.name: jump camera

words.def: The Jump Jacket[34] is a harness with integral buoyancy jacket specifically designed for commercial diving work with helmets and bells.
words.name: Jump jacket

words.def:
See also: Cave diving
A short cave line used to connect between two permanent lines that are not in contact. May also be used to search for the other end of a break in a cave line and repair the break
words.name: jump line

words.def: A reel or spool with a relatively short line intended to be used as a jump line (q.v.).
words.name: jump spool

words.def:
Further information: Diving cylinder § Types of cylinder valve
Scuba cylinder valve with lever operated reserve mechanism.[35]
words.name: J-valve

words.def:
Main article: Kayak diving
Diving from a special purpose kayak used to get to the site where the distance from a suitable entry and exit point is inconvenient for shore diving.
words.name: kayak diving

words.def:
Further information: Diving cylinder § Types of cylinder valve
Scuba cylinder valve without reserve mechanism.
words.name: K-valve

words.def:
Main article: Lanyard
A piece of cordage used to secure or lower things, usually it is used where there is a risk of losing the object
words.name: lanyard

words.def: Launch and Recovery System (q.v.
words.name: LARS

words.def: Mechanised system for launching and recovery of a diving bell, diving stage, submersible or ROV from a vessel, offshore platform, dockside or other platform.
words.name: launch and recovery sysytem

words.def:
Main article: Laryngospasm
An uncontrolled/involuntary muscular contraction (spasm) of the laryngeal cords which causes a partial blocking of breathing in, while breathing out remains easier.
words.name: laryngospasm

words.def:
also pipelay barge
Barge on which pipeline sections are assembled, welded and laid on the seabed as the barge is moved forward.[3]
words.name: lay barge

words.def:
Further information: Diving shot § Lazy shot
Shot line (q.v.) which does not reach the bottom
words.name: lazy shot

words.def: Local dive shop
words.name: LDS

words.def: Light emitting diode, commonly used in dive lights.
words.name: LED

words.def: A line connected securely to the diver at one end and anchored at the other end at the diving control point, which is handled by a line tender, and is used to communicate with the diver and provide a means of finding the diver for a surface standby diver, and for assisting the diver to the surface and back to the control point if necessary.
words.name: lifeline

words.def: see LST
words.name: life support technician

words.def:
Main article: Lifting bag
A robust and air-tight bag with straps, which is used to lift heavy objects underwater by means of the bag's buoyancy.
words.name: lifting bag

words.def: The part of a canister light (q.v.) which emits light, and is held in the hand or mounted on the helmet.
words.name: light head

words.def:
Main article: Diving helmet § Lightweight demand helmets
Low volume, close fitting diving helmet, usually with demand valve. Neutrally buoyant, and moves with the diver's head.
words.name: lightweight helmet

words.def: Line arrows, cookies and sometimes clothes pegs. Used to indicate direction to exit, midway point between exits, jumps and personal markers to identify divers on a guide line.
words.name: line marker

words.def: Narrow gap where the guide line passes but divers can not get through.[5]
words.name: line trap

words.def:
Main article: Lipid pneumonia
A lung inflammation (pneumonia) that develops when lipids enter the bronchial tree
words.name: lipid pneumonia

words.def:
Main article: Liveaboard
A large boat which provides transport, accommodation and services for vacationing divers
words.name: live-aboard

words.def: 1.  Working diver leaving the closed bell into the water.
words.name: lockout

words.def: Comparment of a hyperbaric habitat or chamber which can be entered through two or more openings which can be closed and sealed, and the pressure adjusted relative to the adjacent chambers. Used to transfer personnel or equipment between areas of different pressure.
words.name: lock

words.def: Record of dives kept as proof of experience. Optional for recreational divers, but legally required for professional divers in many jurisdictions.
words.name: log book

words.def: 5 ft to 7 ft interstage hose used on one of the regulators used by cave and other technical divers, which allows gas sharing through narrow spaces.
words.name: long hose

words.def:
Main article: Longshore current
Mass transport of water along a shoreline, generally due to wave action at an angle to the shoreline.
words.name: longshore current

words.def:
also breathing loop
Main article: Rebreather § The loop
The circuit in a rebreather through which the breathing gas passes during a breathing cycle.
words.name: loop

words.def: volume of the breathing loop of a rebreather.
words.name: loop volume

words.def: standardised procedure followed when a diver realises that their buddy is not where they should be. Procedures may vary depending on the circumstances and training organisations.
words.name: lost buddy drill

words.def: Standardised procedure to be followed when the guideline to the surface is lost in a penetration dive, often in conditions of low visibility and darkness.
words.name: lost line drill

words.def: low pressure
words.name: LP

words.def: Low pressure compressor. Used for breathing air supply for surface supplied air diving.
words.name: LP compressor

words.def: Low pressure cylinder (US) with working pressure less thsn 2500psi.
words.name: LP cylinder

words.def: Opening on the first stage of a regulator through which regulated gas is supplied.
words.name: LP port

words.def: Life support technician: A person who operates the life support systems the surface components of a saturation diving system.
words.name: LST

words.def: see twin cylinder manifold
words.name: manifold

words.def:
also manufacturing code
Set of design and manufacturing rules intended to produce uniform and safe products by several manufacturers in an industry.
words.name: manufacturing standard

words.def: One of the popular underwater plug connector systems for diver communications cables.[37]
words.name: Marsh Marine connector

words.def: Rough rule of thumb for estimating nitrogen narcosis effects based on equivalence to consumption of dry martinis: Variously quoted as one martini per 10m or one martini per 50ft depth.
words.name: Martini's law

words.def: (Rigging) The large heavy duty link to which the legs of a chain sling are attached, and which is the attachment point on the sling for the lifting hook or shackle
words.name: master link

words.def: Cave structure characterised by multiple branches and changes in direction.
words.name: maze cave

words.def: Manual Closed Circuit Rebreather: A closed cirduit rebreather which relies on the diver to control the gas mixture in the loop.
words.name: MCCR

words.def: Microscopic bubbles which are not detectable by ultrasound or Doppler ultrasound, yet can affect the likelihood of DCS by slowing off-gassing.[4]
words.name: microbubbles

words.def: Microscopic cavities that function as bubble seeds by absorbing dissolved gas.[4]
words.name: micronuclei

words.def: Small lock on a decompression chamber used for transfer of medical equipment and other supplies into and out of the chamber while the chamber remains under pressure.
words.name: medical lock

words.def: Short for trimix breathing gas
words.name: mix

words.def: Breathing gas for diving other than air, but usually implies a helium based mixture.
words.name: mixed gas

words.def: Maximum operating depth: Limiting depth for safety based on partial pressure of oxygen of a breathing gas mixture.
words.name: MOD

words.def: Version of the flutter kick finning style which reduces risk of silting by directing thrust more directly backwards. Two techniques exist: One version has the legs bent at the knees so that the fins are placed relatively high and on average are aligned more horizontally. The other version has one fin stationary below the moving fin to deflect downwash.[5] Leg movement is restrained, and ankle movement used for precision manoeuvring.
words.name: modified flutter kick

words.def: Version of the frog kick finning style which reduces risk of silting by directing thrust more directly backwards. Performed with bent knees and fins raised above the line of the torso.
words.name: modified frog kick

words.def: Mobile offshore drilling unit - a generic term for several classes of self-contained floatable or floating drilling rigs such as drilling vessels, semisubmersibles, submersibles, jack-ups, and similar facilities that can be moved without substantial effort. These facilities may have self-propulsion equipment on board and may require dynamic positioning equipment or mooring systems to maintain their position.[38]
words.name: MODU

words.def:
Main article: Monofin
A type of swimfin typically used in finswimming and free-diving. It consists of a single surface attached to footpockets for both of the diver's feet.
words.name: monofin

words.def:
Main article: Molecular sieve
Material containing tiny pores of a precise and uniform size that is used as an adsorbent for gases and liquids. Molecules small enough to pass through the pores are absorbed while larger molecules are not. It is different from a common filter in that it operates on a molecular level.
words.name: molecular sieve

words.def:
Further information: Side mount diving § Terminology
The use of sidemount configuration and procedures with a single cylinder.
words.name: monkey diving

words.def:
Main article: Moonpool
An opening in the floor or base of the hull, platform, or chamber giving access to the water below.
words.name: moonpool

words.def: metres sea water: Unit of pressure equal to 1/10 bar. Not a linear measure of depth.[39]
words.name: msw

words.def: A dive profile in which the diver remains in more than one distinct depth ranges for a significant period before beginning final ascent to the surface (excluding decompression stops).
words.name: multilevel dive

words.def: A brown organic deposit usually found on the ceilings of caves which is easily dislodged by diver's exhaust bubbles and then drifts down through the water.
words.name: mung

words.def:
Further information: Gas compressor § Reciprocating compressors
Compressor in which gases are compressed more than once, often with cooling between stages. Used to improve efficiency and reduce temperatures.
words.name: multiple stage compressor

words.def: A rubber non-return valve flap which is circular or oval, with a stem in the middle to attach it to the holder in the centre of the grating over the orifice.
words.name: mushroom valve

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § M-values
At a given ambient pressure, the M-value is the maximum theoretical value of absolute inert gas pressure that a tissue compartment can take without presenting symptoms of decompression sickness.
words.name: M-value

words.def: National Association for Cave Diving
words.name: NACD

words.def: see nitrogen narcosis
words.name: narcs

words.def:
Main article: U.S. Navy SEALs
A US Navy trained combat diver.
words.name: Navy SEAL

words.def:
Further information: Decompression practice § No decompression limit
No decompression limit. The maximum time which a diver can remain at a specified depth without incurring a stage decompression obligation in terms of the specified decompression tables or algorithm.
words.name: NDL

words.def: The lower part of a lightweight diving helmet which includes a neoprene or latex neck seal to prevent ingress of water. The alternative is to clamp the helmet to the diver'e drysuit.
words.name: neck dam

words.def: US Navy Experimental Diving Unit
words.name: NEDU

words.def:
also neo-Haldanean
Main article: Decompression theory § Critical difference hypothesis
Decompression models based on later modifications of the principles described by John Scott Haldane.
words.name: neo-Haldanian

words.def:
Main article: Neoprene
Synthetic elastomer used in the form of foamed sheets as the material for most wetsuits and some drysuits.
words.name: neoprene

words.def:
Main article: Newtsuit
An atmospheric diving suit designed and originally built by Phil Nuytten.
words.name: Newtsuit

words.def: A handle with a hooked blade used to cut netting or cordage to free the diver from entanglement
words.name: net cutter

words.def: Non-freezing cold injuries: Permanent tissue damage due to low temperature exposure without any freezing damage.
words.name: NFCI

words.def:
Further information: Decompression sickness § Signs and symptoms
Minor symptoms characteristic of mild decompression sickness.
words.name: niggles

words.def:
Main article: Night diving
Diving during the hours of darkness.
words.name: night diving

words.def: Nickel-metal hydride. A technology for rechargeable battery cells.
words.name: NiMH

words.def:
Main article: Nitrile rubber
A synthetic elastomer used for most standard O-ring seals.
words.name: nitrile

words.def:
Main article: Nitrogen
The major component gas of air and many breathing gas mixtures used in diving. Important in diving as an active agent in nitrogen narcosis and decompression sickness.
words.name: nitrogen

words.def:
Main article: Nitrogen narcosis
Also known as narcs, inert gas narcosis, raptures of the deep, Martini effect: A reversible alteration in consciousness that occurs while breathing gases containing nitrogen under elevated partial pressure similar to alcohol intoxication or nitrous oxide inhalation, and can occur during shallow dives, but usually does not become noticeable until greater depths, beyond 30 meters.
words.name: nitrogen narcosis

words.def:
also Enriched Air Nitrox (EAN)
Main article: Nitrox
Mixture of nitrogen and oxygen for use as breathing gas. Usually with oxygen percentage higher than air.
words.name: nitrox

words.def:
Further information: Gas blending § Mixing the gases
A mixing tube used to blend oxygen with air before compressing to make nitrox breathing gas.
words.name: nitrox stick

words.def: National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration (US)
words.name: NOAA

words.def: Volume of free gas contained by a scuba cylinder when filled to charging pressure at constant temperature.
words.name: nominal capacity

words.def:
Further information: Side mount diving § Terminology
A specialized overhead-environment strategy for dealing with particularly tight restrictions which may involve divers wearing a very basic harness or simply hand-carrying cylinders.
words.name: No-mount diving

words.def: 1.  A breathing gas mixture with oxygen content approximating atmospheric air.
words.name: normoxic

words.def: National Speleological Society
words.name: NSS

words.def:
Main article: Nystagmus
An oscillation of the eyes alternating a slow eye movement in one direction, and a fast eye movement in the other direction
words.name: nystagmus

words.def: Sharing air using an octopus regulator
words.name: octopus breathing

words.def:
also octo reg
Further information: Diving regulator § Octopus
A secondary demand valve fitted to a first stage diving regulator for use as an alternative air source for another diver in case of an emergency.
words.name: octopus regulator

words.def: see outgassing
words.name: off-gassing

words.def: Colloquial term for a diver who works in the offshore oil and gas industry.[3]
words.name: offshore diver

words.def: Method for installation of sub-sea pipeline for the oil and gas industry. The pipe is constructed in an onshore construction yard, moved into the water and bent into a spiral without causing plastic deformation of the material. When the pipeline is sufficiently long it is transported with the help of tugs to the installation area. At the installation area the pipeline is unwound and pulled over a simple lay barge with stinger and installed on the bottom.[40][self-published source?][original research?]
words.name: O-lay

words.def: see ingassing
words.name: on-gassing

words.def: Breathing apparatus which discharges exhaled gas into the environment, without any further use.
words.name: open circuit

words.def: Out of air: An emergency situation where the supply of breathing gas to the diver has stopped.
words.name: OOA

words.def: 1.  Water where there is no physical obstruction to a direct ascent to the surface.[41]
words.name: open water

words.def: Over-pressure valve. A pressure relief valve which automatically opens at a set pressure to allow excess gas to escape.
words.name: OPV

words.def:
Main article: O-ring
A mechanical gasket in the shape of a torus; a loop of elastomer with a circular cross-section, designed to be seated in a groove and compressed during assembly between two or more parts, creating a seal at the contact surfaces.
words.name: O-ring

words.def: A breathing mask that covers the mouth and the nose only. It may occur independently, as an oxygen mask, or it may occur inside a full face diving mask or helmet to reduce the amount of dead space
words.name: oro-nasal mask

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § Outgassing of tissues
Diffusion of gas out of the tissue into the blood, and transport to the lungs where it diffuses into the lung gas and is eliminated by exhalation.
words.name: outgassing

words.def: A physical or procedural obstruction to a direct ascent to the surface. Physical overheads include cave, cavern or culvery ceilings, fishing nets, ship hulls, and wreckage. Procedural overheads are generally a decompression obligation.
words.name: overhead

words.def:
see also diving heavy
Carrying more weight than is necessary to achieve neutral buoyancy at all times in a dive.
words.name: overweighting

words.def:
Main article: Oxygen
Important component gas of atmospheric air and essential component of any breathing gas. Required to sustain life.
words.name: oxygen

words.def:
Main article: Oxygen analyzer
Instrument for measuring the partial pressure of oxygen in a gas mixture
words.name: oxygen analyzer

words.def: Cleaned for oxygen service by appropriate methods and materials and tested for contaminants.Verified that particulates, fibres, oils, greases and other contaminants are absent.[30]
words.name: oxygen clean

words.def:
Further information: Oxygen toxicity § Underwater
A notional alarm clock, which accumulates hyperbaric oxygen exposure at a rate which increases with higher ppO2 toward the maximum single exposure limit recommended
words.name: oxygen clock

words.def: Made from materials which are suitable for oxygen service. Capable of coexisting with elevated oxygen concentrations and a potential source of ignition without flashing, based on a system’s maximum operating pressure and temperature.[30]
words.name: oxygen compatible

words.def: Air which has been filtered to reduce contaminants to a level suitable for blending with high pressure oxygen. Air with a reduced level of condensable hydrocarbon mist or vapour.[30]
words.name: oxygen compatible air

words.def: Design that minimizes any tendency for heat generation, ignition of particulates, or the accumulation of contaminants for an intended partial pressure of oxygen and temperature.[30]
words.name: oxygen design

words.def:
Further information: Fraction of inspired oxygen
Fraction by volume or pressure of the gas mixture made up by oxygen
words.name: oxygen fraction

words.def: Mythical monster associated with CNS oxygen toxicity, also CNS oxygen toxicity seizure.
words.name: Oxygen Pete

words.def: Suitable for operating with significantly higher levels of oxygen than normal atmospheric air. Often implies special cleaning procedures, use of oxygen compatible materials, and design to reduce ignition risk. System or component that has been designed and tested for oxygen use, has been tested as oxygen clean and is oxygen compatible.[30]
words.name: oxygen service

words.def:
Main article: Oxygen toxicity
A condition resulting from the harmful effects of breathing molecular oxygen (O2) at elevated partial pressures.
words.name: oxygen toxicity

words.def:
Main article: Oxygen window in technical diving
Inherent unsaturation due to metabolic reduction of total gas pressure in the tissues.
words.name: oxygen window

words.def:
Main article: Panic
A sudden sensation of fear which is so strong as to dominate or prevent reason and logical thinking, replacing it with overwhelming feelings of anxiety and frantic agitation consistent with an animalistic fight-or-flight reaction
words.name: panic

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § Perfusion limited tissues and parallel tissue models
A decompression model comprising a group of tissues with varied rates of perfusion, but supplied by blood of approximately equivalent gas concentration. It is assumed that there is no gas transfer between tissue compartments by diffusion. This results in a parallel set of independent tissues, each with its own rate of ingassing and outgassing dependent on the rate of blood flowing through the tissue
words.name: parallel compartments

words.def:
Main article: Partial pressure
(Abbreviation PP or pp) The pressure that a component gas of a gas mixture would exert if it alone was present in the volume occupied by the gas mixture.
words.name: partial pressure

words.def:
see also Rebreather#Passive addition semi-closed circuit
Feed gas addition system for semi-closed circuit rebreathers which discharges a part of the gas in the breathing circuit. fresh gas is added when the volume of the circuit decreases during inhalation and triggers the addition valve. Compare with active addition
words.name: passive addition

words.def: Also push-pull rebreather. Rebreather with a single breathing hose from the mouthpiece to the scrubber and counterlung. Gas passes through it in both directions, unlike the one-way breathing loop configuration. The volume of the hose between the mouthpiece and scrubber is dead space
words.name: pendulum rebreather

words.def:
Further information: Penetration diving
Entering a region with no direct vertical access to the surface, such as a cave or the interior of a wreck.
words.name: penetration

words.def: see distance line
words.name: penetration line

words.def: Cave diving: Bubbles making their way to the walls and the ceiling of the cave and dislodging silt.[43]
words.name: percolation

words.def:
Main article: Perfusion
The process of delivery of blood to a capillary bed in the biological tissue.[4]
words.name: perfusion

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § Deterministic models
The assumption in a decompression model that perfusion has the dominant influence on gas uptake and release.
words.name: perfusion limited

words.def:
also PLB
Main article: Distress radiobeacon
Radio beacons for personal use which are intended to indicate a person in distress who is away from normal emergency services.
words.name: personal locator beacon

words.def:
Main article: Personal protective equipment
Equipment worn by personnel to reduce risk of injury at sites where it is not practicable to eliminate the hazard, including ear protectors, safety glasses, hard hats, gloves, overalls, respirators etc.
words.name: personal safety equipment

words.def: patent foramen ovale: A form of congenital heart defect that enables blood flow between the left and right atria through a gap in the interatrial septum.
words.name: PFO

words.def:
see also jump camera
A photograph of a quadrat taken for later analysis. Common in marine ecological research where in situ counting would be impractical. Quadrats may be identified by rigid frames or by a fixed camera to subject distance.
words.name: photo quadrat

words.def:
Further information: Pigging § Pipeline Inspection Gauge
Pipeline inspection gauge: A tool that is sent through a pipeline and propelled by the pressure of the product in the pipeline itself.
words.name: pig

words.def: Coiled section of pipe to provide greater flexibility.
words.name: pigtail

words.def: see cylinder valve
words.name: pillar valve

words.def:
Main article: Pin Index Safety System
Standard connection type for portable medical oxygen cylinder valves and regulators.
words.name: pin index connection

words.def: Securing the guideline as it is being run and the choice of primary and secondary tie offs.[5]
words.name: placements

words.def: see personal locator beacon
words.name: PLB

words.def: Pipeline end manifold:. Point where flexible underwater hose string is attached to connect seabed pipeline with Single point mooring.[3]
words.name: PLEM

words.def: Use of the pneumofathometer hose to supply breathing gas to a surface supplied diver in an emergency. Supply can be from the diver's own pneumo hose or from a standby diver's pneumo hose.
words.name: pneumo breathing

words.def:
also pneumo
Instrument to measure depth of a diver using a gauge calibrated in msw, fsw, or often both, to measure the ambient pressure at the diver by measuring the pressure in a hose filled with air with an open end at the diver.
words.name: pneumofathometer

words.def:
Main article: Pneumothorax
Air or other breathing gas in the chest cavity, often resulting in a collapsed lung.
words.name: pneumothorax

words.def: (of compressor) Compresses gas by reducing volume of compression chamber (cylinder) by mechanical means (piston) to produce higher pressure of the contents.
words.name: positive displacement

words.def:
Main article: pony cylinder
Relatively small scuba set carried as an independent alternative breathing gas source by a scuba diver.
words.name: pony cylinder

words.def: A large bore quick connector fitting designed and used by Draeger on diving and firefighting breathing apparatus, which has been used in rebreathers, particularly modifications.
words.name: P-port

words.def: Examination of the external condition of a pressure vessel and fittings to ensure that it complies with requirements before accepting for filling.[13]
words.name: pre-fill external inspection

words.def: Nitrox blend with high oxygen content used to mix nitrox by topping up the decanted premix with air.
words.name: pre-mix

words.def: The rate of change of partial pressure of dissolved gas through a solvent, which is the driving mechanism for diffusion through the solvent. Also loosely used to refer to the difference between the dissolved gas pressure in a tissue and ambient pressure.[4]
words.name: pressure gradient

words.def: The main light to be used on a dive. Usually the most powerful.
words.name: primary light

words.def: the regulator which the diver intends to breathe from for most of the dive. Particularly when diving with back-mounted manifolded twin cylinders.
words.name: primary regulator

words.def: First tie off of the guideline in a penetration dive. This is usually made in a place with free vertical access to the surface.
words.name: primary tie-off

words.def:
Main article: Professional diving
Diving which is done as part of the diver's employment or professional occupation.
words.name: professional diving

words.def: An incremental approach to cave and wreck exploration. Each dive goes a bit further so that the divers develop a familiarity with the environment.[5]
words.name: progressive penetration

words.def: Pressure relief valve
words.name: PRV

words.def: Pounds per square inch. Unit of pressure in the Imperial system.
words.name: psi

words.def: Push to talk: Voice communication systems which require the user to press a button to transmit. Used with through water systems to conserve battery power.
words.name: PTT

words.def:
Main article: public safety diving
The underwater work conducted by law enforcement, fire department rescue, and search & rescue/recovery dive teams.
words.name: public safety diving

words.def: A relatively long pull on a lifeline when used for rope signals. (see "bell" for comparison).
words.name: pull

words.def: To press the purge button on a demand valve to induce a gas flow which is intended to clear the demand valve interior of water or other substances.
words.name: purge

words.def: Button or flexible area on the front or side of a demand valve which allows the user to manually open the second stage valve to provide gas flow without inhalation.
words.name: purge button

words.def: Valve in snorkel or mask which allows water to drain either under gravity or as a result of exhalation into the air space
words.name: purge valve

words.def: Tech diving jargon: Decompress at a high gradient factor, particularly when exceeding the baseline M-value.[44]
words.name: push gradient

words.def: see pendulum rebreather
words.name: push-pull rebreather

words.def:
also Pee-valve
Further information: Dry suit § The P-valve
A valved catheter fitted to a dry suit, which enables a diver to urinate at any time without having to get out of the water.
words.name: P-valve

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § Pyle stops
Named after Richard Pyle, an early advocate of deep stops. An additional brief deep decompression stop, typically 2 minutes long and half way between the maximum depth and the first conventional decompression stop.
words.name: Pyle stops

words.def: Oval connector shaped like a chain link with a screw gate on one side.
words.name: quick link

words.def: A group of high pressure gas storage cylinders mounted upright on a frame and manifolded together. Usually in 4, 6, 9, 12, or 16 cylinder arrangements.
words.name: quad

words.def:
Main article: quadrat
see also photo quadrat
A small, typically rectangular plot used in ecology and geography to isolate a standard unit of area for study of the distribution of an item over a large area. The quadrat is suitable for sampling plants and slow-moving or sessile animals.
words.name: quadrat

words.def: Also cobra guard. Frame attached to the top of the cylinders to protect valves, manifold, and regulator first stages from impact with the surroundings.
words.name: rams head

words.def: see nitrogen narcosis
words.name: rapture of the deep

words.def: Also known as rash guard, or rashie, A shirt made of spandex and nylon or polyester to protect against rashes caused by abrasion. These shirts can be worn by themselves, in tropical water, or under a wetsuit.
words.name: rash vest

words.def: Ratcliffe diving helmet, Designed by Bob Ratcliffe, later produced by Oceaneering International. No longer in production.[45]
words.name: Rat hat

words.def:
also ratio deco
Main article: Ratio decompression
A technique for calculating decompression schedules for scuba divers engaged in deep diving without using dive tables, decompression software or a dive computer.[46][47]
words.name: ratio decompression

words.def:
Main article: Rebreather
Breathing apparatus which recycles most of the exhaled gas, removing carbon dioxide and topping up oxygen before the gas is breathed again.
words.name: rebreather

words.def:
Main article: Reciprocating compressor
Compressor in which the volume of the compression chamber/s is cyclically changed by reversing linear motion. E.g.: a piston moving back and forth in a cylinder.
words.name: reciprocating compressor

words.def:
See also: Saturation diving
Diving helmet with a reclaim gas regulator allowing exhaled gas to be safely returned to the surface through an additional hose on the umbilical.
words.name: reclaim helmet

words.def:
See also: Saturation diving
System for recovering helium based breathing gas used by divers and recycling it.
words.name: reclaim system

words.def: Subjecting a diver to pressure after an ascent from a dive as treatment for decompression illness or to prevent decompression sickness. Preferably done in a recompression chamber, but occasionally done as in-water recompression.
words.name: recompression

words.def:
Main article: Recompression chamber
A hyperbaric chamber used to treat divers suffering from certain diving disorders such as decompression sickness.
words.name: recompression chamber

words.def:
Main article: Recreational diving
Recreational diving or sport diving is a type of diving that uses scuba equipment for the purpose of leisure and enjoyment. In some diving circles, the term "recreational diving" is used in contradistinction to "technical diving", a more demanding aspect of the sport which requires greater levels of training, experience and equipment. In other circles, technical diving is considered a subset of recreational diving as opposed to professional diving, which is done as part of the diver's work.
words.name: recreational diving

words.def:
also RDP
Main article: Recreational Dive Planner
A no-stop decompression table developed by DSAT.
words.name: Recreational Dive Planner

words.def: see algal bloom
words.name: red tide

words.def: Mechanism used to store, deploy and recover long lengths of line.
words.name: reel

words.def: 1.  A mechanism for controlling the output pressure of a high pressure gas supply.
words.name: regulator

words.def:
Further information: Ice diving § Regulator freezing
Locking of the regulator mechanism caused by freezing of the water due to expansion cooling of the regulated air. Often causes the mechanism to lock open, causing free flow and further cooling.
words.name: regulator freeze

words.def: Features, states or conditions which are not acceptable.[13]
words.name: reject criteria

words.def:
Further information: Decompression practice § Repetitive dives
Any dive which is done while the tissues retain residual inert gas from a previous dive.
words.name: repetitive dives

words.def: Method of estimating tolerable repetitive exposure to high partial pressure oxygen.[48]
words.name: Repex

words.def:
Further information: Scuba gas planning § Reserve pressure
Gas which is not intended to be used during the dive, and is reserved for contingencies.
words.name: reserve gas

words.def: Cylinder valve with a lever operated bypass valve to release the gas below reserve pressure
words.name: reserve valve

words.def: Gas remaining in a cylinder from the previous fill.
words.name: residual gas

words.def:
See also: Decompression practice § Residual nitrogen time
Nitrogen in excess of normal atmospheric saturation remaining in the diver's tissues after a dive.
words.name: residual nitrogen

words.def:
also RNT
See also: Decompression practice § Residual nitrogen time
Time penalty in a repetitive dive equivalent to time at depth which would produce the residual nitrogen in the diver at the start of the dive.
words.name: residual nitrogen time

words.def: Pressure of the gas remaining in a cylinder from the previous fill.
words.name: residual pressure

words.def:
Main article: Respiratory quotient
The ratio of carbon dioxide produced as a metabolic product to the oxygen consumed.
words.name: respiratory quotient

words.def: Section of a cave which is difficult to pass through due to lack of space. A minor restriction is too small for two divers to swim through together, a major restriction requires the diver to remove equipment to fit through.
words.name: restriction

words.def: Procedure to cross a gap which allows the line to be retrieved without returning to the start point.
words.name: reverse jump

words.def: Repetitive dive which is deeper than the previous dive
words.name: reverse profile

words.def:
also reduced gradient bubble model
Main article: Reduced gradient bubble model
A bubble model decompression algorithm developed by Bruce Wienke.
words.name: RGBM

words.def: System of touch contact signalling. Push forward = go, pull back = back up, squeeze = stop.[5]
words.name: Rimbach system

words.def:
see also bungee (sidemount)
Length of shock cord with metal rings and a clip used to control the position of the top end of a sidemounted cylinder.[10] Differs from a regular bungee in having the rings.[10] A popular configuration is a bolt snap connected to a ring by a quick link, with a length of bungee from the ring to another quick link which is used to connect the assembly to a D-ring on the back of the harness. The bolt snap is clipped to the shoulder D-ring and the cylinder neck bolt snap is clipped to the ring.
words.name: ring bungee

words.def:
Main article: Rip current
A strong localised flow of water to seaward from near the shore, typically through the surf line
words.name: rip current

words.def:
Main article: Drilling riser
A conduit that provides a temporary extension of a subsea oil well to a surface drilling facility
words.name: riser

words.def: Respiratory minute volume: (or minute ventilation) The volume of gas inhaled (inhaled minute volume) or exhaled (exhaled minute volume) from a person's lungs in one minute.
words.name: RMV

words.def: Royal Navy Physiological Laboratory
words.name: RNPL

words.def: see residual nitrogen time
words.name: RNT

words.def:
see also Scuba gas planning
Retention of a breathing gas reserve based on calculated values for the amount of gas required for a safe ascent from any point in the planned dive profile. Factors such as emergency supply of gas to a buddy, air consumption rates under stress and decompression gas requirements are considered in the calculations.
words.name: rock bottom gas management

words.def: Closing of a cylinder valve as a result of scraping contact between the valve knob and the overhead or other surroundings.
words.name: roll-off

words.def: Remotely operated underwater vehicle.
words.name: ROV

words.def: Member of the drilling crew who works under the direction of the driller to make or break connections as drillpipe is tripped in or out of the hole.[3]
words.name: roughneck

words.def: Any unskilled manual laborer on the rigsite.[3]
words.name: roustabout

words.def:
See also: Scuba gas planning
Cave and wreck penetration breathing gas management convention where no more than one third of the gas in a cylinder may be used on the inward part of the dive, and the other two thirds is kept for exit: One third for the planned exit, and one third in case of an emergency.
words.name: rule of thirds

words.def: Time elapsed since the start of a dive.
words.name: run time

words.def: A pause made during ascent to adjust the average ascent rate to the nominal value. For example a nominal ascent rate of 3 m per minute might use an actual ascent rate of about 5 m per minute and make a stop every 3m until the end of the current minute, resulting in a slightly stepped profile with an overall ascent rate corresponding to the nominal rate.[46]
words.name: running stop

words.def: Decompression schedule and dive plan based on elapsed time from the start of the dive, All waypoints and events are specified in terms of elapsed time with start of descent at zero.
words.name: run time schedule

words.def:
also: Positive reserve valve, automatic valve, or calibrated orifice
A cylinder valve which limits the outflow by a calibrated orifice when in the "on" position.[35]
words.name: R-valve

words.def: Surface Air Consumption rate: A measure of air consumption in units of pressure over time, usually psi/minute, adjusted to surface pressure, used to estimate air endurance of a cylinder of specific size. Useful for those who work in imperial units.[49] SAC has a constant value for a given diver and represents gas used on the surface at rest.[21] Surface Gas Consumption (SGC) is an alternative term referring to alternative breathing gas mixtures. Occasionally also termed Surface Consumption Rate (SCR)[50][51] - not to be confused with Semi-closed Rebreather (SCR).
words.name: SAC rate

words.def: Term used for nitrox by ANDI (American Nitrox Divers International)
words.name: safe air

words.def: Obsolete term for backup regulator.
words.name: safe second

words.def: Reel for use in an emergency, usually for searches to find lost buddy or lost guideline or to jump a line break. Relatively short line.
words.name: safety reel

words.def:
Further information: Decompression practice § Safety stop
A voluntary (not required by the decompression schedule) additional decompression stop intended to reduce risk of decompression sickness.
words.name: safety stop

words.def:
Main article: Salt water aspiration syndrome
A reaction of the lungs to inhalation of a mist of salt water
words.name: salt water aspiration syndrome

words.def: Contractions experienced by breathhold divers when approaching hypoxic blackout.[52]
words.name: samba

words.def:
Main article: Saturation diving
Diving procedure where the divers remain pressurised for periods of several days or weeks and decompress only at the end of the period.
words.name: saturation diving

words.def: Saturation diving system.
words.name: saturation spread

words.def: Self Contained Breathing Apparatus (not for underwater use).
words.name: SCBA

words.def: Diving for purposes of scientific research. The rules and constraints of scientific diving vary in different jurisdictions, but generally allow more options than mainstream commercial diving.
words.name: scientific diving

words.def: Diver propulsion vehicle used by scuba divers to increase range underwater.
words.name: scooter

words.def: D-ring on harness used to attach to scooter tow line. Usually on front of crotch strap.
words.name: scooter ring

words.def: Semi-closed circuit rebreather: A rebreather (q.v.) which either dumps part of each breath to the environment or continuously adds gas and dumps the excess. Compare with closed circuit rebreather (CCR) (q.v.).
words.name: SCR

words.def:
Main article: Carabiner
A clip mechanism which can be locked in the closed position by turning a threaded barrel.
words.name: screw gate carabiner

words.def:
Main article: Rebreather § Carbon dioxide scrubber
Canister containing material (sorb) which chemically combines with carbon dioxide to remove it from the gas passed through the canister.
words.name: scrubber

words.def:
also SCUBA
Main article: Scuba set
Self Contained Underwater Breathing Apparatus. May be open or closed circuit.
words.name: scuba

words.def:
Main article: Scuba orienteering
Competitive underwater sport in which scuba divers attempt to swim a circuit marked by buoys, without surfacing, using compass navigation and mechanical distance measurement. Points are awarded for time and accuracy according to the specific course definition and length.
words.name: scuba orienteering

words.def: Surface supplied diving equipment using portable gas storage cylinders for primary and reserve breathing gas supply. Preferred to scuba for commercial diving applications due to lower perceived risk compared to scuba, and because equipment and procedures are otherwise identical to surface supplied diving using compressors for air supply. Used when logistical constraints or air quality issues preclude use of a compressor.
words.name: scuba replacement

words.def: Safety drill. An air sharing exercise based on deploying the long hose primary regulator.
words.name: S-drill

words.def:
Main article: Underwater searches
Cord used to indicate the transect for a search. The diver moves along the line, searching by sight or feel on one or both sides of the line. After the transect has been searched, the line is moved to the next transect. usually a short distance offset from the previous position, at a distance which depends on the visibility and the size of the target.
words.name: search line

words.def:
Main article: Underwater searches
Systematic procedure for covering the search area sufficiently to be reasonably sure of finding a given target. Several patterns are in general use for underwater searches, depending on the target, the terrain, and available facilities.
words.name: search pattern

words.def:
Main article: Secondary drowning
A complication of aspiration of water or other fluids into the lungs.
words.name: secondary drowning

words.def:
see demand valve
The part of a diving regulator which provides pressure reduction from intermediate pressure to ambient pressure on demand. Demand valve.
words.name: second stage

words.def:
Main article: Diving suit
A wet suit with wrist and ankle seals, and usually a more watertight zipper than usual, to reduce flushing of water through the suit.
words.name: semi-dry suit

words.def:
Main article: Vapor–liquid separator
Device which facilitates the separation of liquid particles from the compressed gas, usually with a drain to periodically remove accumulated liquid from the system.
words.name: separator

words.def:
Main article: Decompression theory § Diffusion limited tissues and the "Tissue slab", and series models
A decompression model based on the assumption that diffusion is the limiting mechanism of dissolved gas transport in the tissues, in which there is perfusion transport for one compartment, and diffusion between a series of compartments,
words.name: serial compartments

words.def: 1.  Number stamped on the cylinder by the manufacturer in the shoulder area which identifies the cylinder. In combination with the manufacturer’s identification this will be unique to the cylinder.[13]
words.name: serial number

words.def:
seeSAC
Surface Gas Consumption
words.name: SGC

words.def:
Main article: Shallow water blackout
A loss of consciousness caused by cerebral hypoxia towards the end of a breath-hold dive in water typically shallower than five metres (16 feet), when the swimmer does not necessarily experience an urgent need to breathe and has no other obvious medical condition that might have caused it.
words.name: shallow water blackout

words.def:
also: shark shield
Electrical device carried by a diver intended to repel sharks by electrical field pulses.[53]
words.name: shark pod

words.def: see bungee cord
words.name: shock cord

words.def: Diving from a shore entry.
words.name: shore diving

words.def:
Main article: Diving shot
A rope between a float at the surface, and a sufficiently heavy weight holding the rope approximately vertical.
words.name: shot line

words.def:
Main article: Side mount diving § Terminology
A scuba diving equipment configuration which has diving cylinders mounted alongside the diver, below the shoulders and along the hips, instead of on the back of the diver.
words.name: sidemount

words.def:
Main article: Side mount diving § Terminology
The practice of using sidemount configuration (bungee loops and/or buttplate rails) as a means for stowing stage/deco cylinders when otherwise diving in back-mounted scuba
words.name: sidemount staging

words.def:
Main article: Silica gel
A desiccant filter medium used to adsorb water.
words.name: silica gel

words.def:
Main article: Silt-out
A situation when underwater visibility is rapidly reduced to zero, usually when a diver disturbs silt deposits.
words.name: silt-out

words.def: Device which is inserted into silt or sand to provide an anchor point, such as for a tie-off on a cave line.[10] Silt screws are generally stakes made from small bore plastic (PVC) pipe with a sharpened end.
words.name: silt screw

words.def:
Main article: single buoy mooring
A loading buoy anchored offshore, that serves as a mooring point and interconnect for tankers loading or offloading gas or liquid products. SPMs are the link between geostatic subsea manifold connections and weathervaning tankers. They are capable of handling any size ship, even very large crude carriers (VLCC) where no alternative facility is available[3]
words.name: single point mooring

words.def:
Main article: Sinkhole
A natural depression or hole in the Earth's surface caused by karst processes — the chemical dissolution of carbonate rocks - or suffosion processes for example in sandstone
words.name: sinkhole

words.def:
Main article: Sintered
Particulate or granular material bonded together by the application of pressure and sufficient heat to partially melt the surface of the particles and weld them together. The product is usually porous.
words.name: sintered

words.def: Place where water from a stream flows into the ground. also "swallow hole"[5]
words.name: siphon

words.def:
Main article: Skandalopetra diving
A flat stone, usually of marble or granite, weighing between 8 and 14 kg, with rounded corners and edges, and tied to a rope, historically used by Greek sponge free-divers to assist descent. when the diver wishes to ascend the rope is used to signal the tender on the boat who then pulls in the rope. Currently a competitive sport.
words.name: skandalopetra

words.def:
also skins, or dive skins
A lycra suit worn by a diver in warm water or under a wet suit.
words.name: skin

words.def: Breathing pattern where the diver holds each breath a while to conserve breathing gas. Can cause CO2 buildup which can lead to headaches, and reduces physiological reserves in case of an emergency.
words.name: skip breathing

words.def: Method of laying underea pipelines by welding the sections together on the lay barge and deploying them from the stern horizontally guided by a "stinger" - a structure that supports the pipe string to control its bend radius.[54]
words.name: S-lay

words.def: Rigid plastic tablet used for writing messages or notes.
words.name: slate

words.def:
Further information: Diving cylinder § Open-circuit
Independent cylinders with their own regulators carried clipped to the harness at the side of the diver.
words.name: sling cylinder

words.def:
see Y-valve
Further information: Diving cylinder § Other distinguishing features
A cylinder valve with two valved outlets angled to left and right of the centreline
words.name: slingshot valve

words.def: Flexible extension used for operating valve knobs on a manifold
words.name: slob knob

words.def: Surface marker buoy.
words.name: SMB

words.def: Line used for underwater search intended to snag on the target. May be dragged by boats or by divers. May be weighted if dragged over a smooth bottom.
words.name: snag line

words.def:
Main article: Snap shackle
A clip connector mechanism which locks when closed, can be operated without tools, and can usually be released under load.
words.name: snap shackle

words.def:
Main article: Snoopy loop
A heavy duty elastic band made from a slice of inner tube.
words.name: snoopy loop

words.def:
Main article: Snorkeling
Tube with a bend and mouthpiece used for breathing air from above the water surface when the wearer's mouth and nose are submerged.
words.name: snorkel

words.def:
also snorkelling
Main article: Snorkeling
Swimming at the surface of the water while breathing through a snorkel. the snorkeller is almost always equipped with a diving mask or swim goggles, and usually swimfins.
words.name: snorkeling

words.def: Device to hold a smorkel in place at the side of a diving mask by fixing it to the mask strap
words.name: snorkel keeper

words.def:
Main article: Snuba
Snuba is portmanteau of "snorkel" and "scuba" referring to a proprietary recreational surface supplied underwater breathing system supplied from a cylinder mounted on a small raft towed by the diver. see also Hookah.
words.name: Snuba

words.def:
Main article: Solo diving
The practice of scuba diving alone, (without a "dive buddy/in-water standby diver").
words.name: solo diving

words.def:
Main article: Choked flow
Metering device to provide constant mass flow of a gas.
words.name: sonic orifice

words.def:
also sodasorb, sodalime and sofnolime
Carbon dioxide absorbent material used in rebreather or life support system scrubber to remove carbon dioxide from the breathing gas so it may be recycled.
words.name: sorb

words.def:
Main article: Speargun
Hunting weapon for shooting fish underwater which propels a barbed steel spear a short distance forward using stored energy from stretched rubber strips or compressed air behind a captive piston.
words.name: speargun

words.def: Slang term for breathhold spearfisher.
words.name: spearo

words.def:
Main article: Speleogen
Dissolution features in bedrock.
words.name: speleogen

words.def:
Main article: Speleothem
Also known as a cave formation: A secondary mineral deposit formed in a cave.
words.name: speleothem

words.def: submersible pressure gauge
words.name: SPG

words.def: Mask strap system for full-face masks with three or more straps. (commonly 5)
words.name: spider

words.def: see single point mooring
words.name: SPM

words.def: Circular device for storing line. No moving parts, small, compact, economical and reliable alternative to a reel for relatively short lines.
words.name: spool

words.def: Place where a concentrated flow of water emerges from the ground.
words.name: spring

words.def: Fin strap using a stainless steel spring to secure the fin to the foot.
words.name: spring strap

words.def: A wetsuit that covers the torso and has short sleeves and long or short legs
words.name: spring suit

words.def: The foot on a leg of a Jack-up type oil platform designed to spread the load so that the rig does not sink too deeply into the sea-bed.[3]
words.name: spud can

words.def: South Pacific Underwater Medicine Society
words.name: SPUMS

words.def: Dive profile where the diver descends continuously to the maximum depth and stays there for the duration of the dive before ascending directly at a stedy rate to the surface or first decompression stop. This profile provides worst case exposure for gas absorption by the body tissues for a given depth and time, and is assumed for decompression planning using decompression tables.
words.name: square profile

words.def:
see barotrauma
Injury or discomfort caused by increase or decrease in volume of gas space in the diver's body or equipment due to a change in ambient pressure.
words.name: squeeze

words.def: Surface Supply Diving Equipment.
words.name: SSDE

words.def: see diving stage
words.name: stage

words.def: 1.  A cylinder used for a stage of a long penetration dive, also known as drop cylinder, which is placed on the distance line to be collected on the return.
words.name: stage cylinder

words.def: The practice of making decompression stops.
words.name: staged decompression

words.def:
Further information: Side mount diving § Terminology
The use of standard deco/stage cylinder configuration, without back-mounted cylinders, on an otherwise standard, or partially modified tec/rec BCD. The cylinders are attached to waist and shoulder D-Rings by direct bolt-snap, and no bungee cord is used in the upper attachment. May be confused with sidemount
words.name: stage-only diving

words.def:
also Copper helmet or Heavy gear
Main article: Standard diving dress
Early free flow surface supplied diving equipment using a heavy canvas suit, copper helmet and corselet, and weighted boots.
words.name: standard diving dress

words.def: Procedure compiled by an organisation prescribing the processes to be followed when performing specified tasks.
words.name: standard operating procedure

words.def: Diver functioning as a safety backup to the working diver. Often on the surface at the dive control point, but ready to enter the water at very short notice on the instruction of the supervisor.
words.name: stand-by diver

words.def: A full one piece wetsuit that covers the torso and the full length of the arms and legs.
words.name: steamer

words.def: An overboard extension at the stern of an offshore pipe lay barge used to provide additional support at the over bend of an S-lay during offshore construction.[54]
words.name: stinger

words.def:
also living depth
Main article: Saturation diving
Depth pressure in a saturation system at which divers live between compression and decompression[39]
words.name: storage depth

words.def: Derogatory term used by DIR zealots to describe divers who do not follow DIR procedures and use DIR approved equipment and configurations.
words.name: stroke

words.def: Gas under the skin resulting from lung overpressure injury.[7]
words.name: subcutaneous emphysema

words.def:
also SPG
Gauge attached to the first stage regulator and used to monitor pressure remaining in the diving cylinder.
words.name: submersible pressure gauge

words.def: Derogatory term for clip mechanisms which are capable of clipping onto a line or other object without the active and intentional intervention of a user.
words.name: suicide clip

words.def: excessive inflation of a dry suit leading to uncontrolled ascent.
words.name: suit blowup

words.def:
Main article: Sump (cave)
A passage in a cave that is submerged under water.
words.name: sump

words.def: Tough waterproof bag with watertight seal used to carry dry equipment in caves, including through water filled passages.[10]
words.name: sump pack

words.def: Rebreather scrubber which not only removes carbon dioxide from the exhaled air, but also replenishes the oxygen by chemical reaction.
words.name: superoxide scrubber

words.def: A temporary and thermodynamically unstable condition of a solvent containing more dissolved gas than it can hold in solution over the long term for the prevailing conditions.
words.name: supersaturation

words.def: The theoretical pressure ratio between tissue gas concentration and ambient pressure above which the probability of bubble formation is unacceptably high.[4]
words.name: supersaturation limit

words.def: EN 14153-1 / ISO 24801-1 standard competence for recreational scuba diver. The level 1 "Supervised Diver" has sufficient knowledge, skill and experience to dive, in open water, to a recommended maximum depth of 12 m, which do not require in-water decompression stops, under the direct supervision of a dive leader, in groups of up to four level 1 scuba divers per dive leader provided the dive leader is capable of establishing physical contact with all level 1 scuba divers at any point during the dive, only when appropriate support is available at the surface, and under conditions that are equal or better than the conditions where they were trained.[55]
words.name: Supervised Diver

words.def: Small lock on a saturation life support habitat for transfer of relatively small items.
words.name: supply lock

words.def: see surface decompression
words.name: SurD

words.def:
Main article: Breaking wave
The mass or line of broken water formed by waves breaking on a shore or reef
words.name: surf

words.def:
Main article: Decompression practice § Surface decompression
A procedure in which some or all of the staged decompression obligation is done in a decompression chamber immediately after surfacing instead of in the water.
words.name: surface decompression

words.def: Equipment, such as flags, surface marker buoys, flares, EPIRBs, mirrors, and whistles, carried by divers to maintain contact with dive boats or attract rescue when lost at sea.
words.name: surface detection aids

words.def: Gas volume adjusted to surface pressure. See also free gas volume
words.name: surface equivalent volume

words.def:
Main article: Decompression practice § Surface interval
The time spent by a diver at surface pressure after a dive during which inert gas which was still present at the end of the dive is further eliminated from the tissues.
words.name: surface interval

words.def:
also SMB
Main article: Surface marker buoy
A buoy towed by a diver to indicate location to people at the surface.
words.name: surface marker buoy

words.def:
Main article: Waves and shallow water
Reciprocating water movement parallel to the bottom surface caused by the passing of a wave overhead
words.name: surge

words.def:
Main article: Sustained load cracking
The development of cracks in a material subjected over long term to static stress significantly less than the yield stress. There is a low but significant risk of this mode of failure in pressure vessels of AA6351 aluminium alloy.[56]
words.name: sustained load cracking

words.def:
Main article: Swell (ocean)
A series of surface gravity waves that is not generated by the local wind.
words.name: swell

words.def: Line used to space divers across the search area for a swim line search. Each diver holds the line at a distance from the previous diver of somewahat less than twuce the visibility distance. The line is used to keep the divers spaced evenly across the search area while swimming perpendicular to the line.
words.name: swim line

words.def:
Main article: Taravana
A form of decompression sickness found among Polynesian island natives who habitually do multiple repetitive deep breath-hold dives.
words.name: taravana

words.def:
Main article: Task loading
A multiplicity of responsibilities leading to an increased risk of failure on the part of the diver to undertake some key basic function which would normally be routine for safety
words.name: task loading

words.def: A constant tension wire from a vessel to a weight on the seabed used as a reference to detect movement of a dynamically positioned vessel from the reference point.[3]
words.name: taut wire system

words.def:
Main article: Technical diving
An extension of the scope of recreational scuba diving to applications with greater technical complexity and higher inherent risk. Definitions vary, but diving with multiple breathing gases, helium based gases, closed circuit rebreathers, or under extensive overheads are generally considered as technical diving. There is no sharp distinction from other forms of recreational diving.
words.name: technical diving

words.def: D-ring welded to a belt slide so that it can not fold down against the webbing. Intended to make it easier to fit and remove snaps.[5]
words.name: tech ring

words.def:
Main article: Tension-leg platform
A vertically moored floating structure normally used for the offshore production of oil or gas, particularly suited for water depths between 300 and 1500 meters. The platform is permanently moored by means of tethers at each of the structure's corners and virtually all vertical motion of the platform is eliminated.
words.name: tension leg rig

words.def: Pressure at which the cylinder will be hydrostatically tested for revalidation. Usually 1.5 or 1.67 x working pressure.[13]
words.name: test pressure

words.def:
Main article: Thalmann algorithm
The Exponential/linear decompression algorithm used in the 2008 US Navy decompression tables
words.name: Thalmann algorithm

words.def:
Further information: Hyperbaric medicine, Decompression practice § Therapeutic decompression, and Decompression sickness § Treatment
A procedure for treating decompression sickness by recompressing the diver, thus reducing bubble size, and allowing the gas bubbles to re-dissolve, then decompressing slowly enough to avoid further formation or growth of bubbles, or eliminating the inert gases by breathing oxygen under pressure
words.name: therapeutic recompression

words.def:
Main article: Thermocline
A thin but distinct layer in a large body of fluid, in which temperature changes more rapidly with depth than it does in the layers above or below
words.name: thermocline

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § The no-supersaturation approach
Hypothesis that bubble formation during decompression will not occur provided absolute ambient pressure exceeds the total of the partial gas tensions in the tissue for each gas.
words.name: thermodynamic decompression model

words.def: see rule of thirds
words.name: thirds

words.def: also bolt and nut shackle, bolt shackle. A shackle which uses a bolt as the pin, secured with a nut. The nut may be locked with a split pin for greater security. The bolt may rotate in the shackle under load without great risk of unscrewing the pin
words.name: three part shackle

words.def: Wireless voice communications transmitted through the water
words.name: through-water communications

words.def: Terminate the dive by signalling exit to surface at a time or place other than the planned turning point.[5]
words.name: thumb the dive

words.def: Friction initiated noisy but relatively harmless pyrotechnic device designed for military exercises, with civilian use for diver recall.[57][58]
words.name: thunderflash

words.def: The surface interval necessary after diving to reduce tissue gas concentrations to a level where the risk of decompression sickness due to the pressure reduction experienced in normal commercial airliners is acceptable.[7]
words.name: time to fly

words.def:
Main article: Tinnitus
The perception of sound within the human ear in the absence of corresponding external sound
words.name: tinnitus

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § Tissue compartments
Imaginary tissues which are designated as fast and slow to describe the rate of saturation.
words.name: tissue compartments

words.def:
Further information: Decompression theory § Tissue half times
The time it takes for the tissue to take up or release 50% of the difference in dissolved gas capacity at a changed partial pressure.
words.name: tissue half times

words.def: 1.  Total Nitrogen Time: Equivalent time of hyperbaric exposure for a repetitive dive used with some decompression tables.
words.name: TNT

words.def: To reconnect a partially filled cylinder and add gas until the pressure is within tolerance of the required charging pressure when corrected for temperature.
words.name: top up

words.def: see Rimbach system
words.name: touch contact signals

words.def:
Main article: Ear clearing
Method of equalising the middle ears by pinching the nose and swallowing.
words.name: Toynbee manouevre

words.def:
Further information: Anxiety § Trait anxiety
A tendency to respond with anxiety in the anticipation of threatening situations.
words.name: trait anxiety

words.def:
Main article: Transect
A path along which one counts and records occurrences of the phenomena of study.
words.name: transect

words.def:
also decant
Fill cylinder with gas by transfer from a cylinder with higher pressure.
words.name: transfill

words.def: High pressure hose and end fittings used to decant between cylinders. Usually includes purge valve and may include pressure gauge.
words.name: transfill whip

words.def:
also bandage scissors or paramedic shears
Main article: Trauma shears
Blunt tipped slightly serrated shears with angled blades sometimes used by divers as a safety cutting implement in place of a knife or line cutter.
words.name: trauma shears

words.def: Gas mixture used for descent and ascent when the bottom gas is not suitable for breathing at shallower depths.
words.name: travel gas

words.def: Pass through a cave by entering at one point and exiting at another.[5]
words.name: traverse

words.def:
Main article: Tremie
A pipe, through which concrete is placed below water level. The top of the tremie is above water and open, and the bottom end is kept below the surface of the poured concrete.
words.name: tremie

words.def: A triangular dive profile is one in which, after a descent at constant rate, and a short bottom time at maximum depth, the diver maintains a constant, slow ascent to the surface or first decompression stop. A plot of depth against elapsed time takes a triangular shape.
words.name: triangular profile

words.def: see belt slide
words.name: triglide

words.def: Material used for dry suit shells made of a layer of waterproof rubber laminated between two layers of woven textile.
words.name: trilam

words.def:
Main article: Trimix (breathing gas)
Mixture of three gases for breathing. Oxygen, nitrogen and helium are the gases used.[30] The gas fractions will usually be specified.
words.name: trimix

words.def:
Further information: Diving weighting system § Trim
Ballast weight placed to improve a diver's trim.
words.name: trim weight

words.def: A seamless transportable compressed gas container, with a water capacity exceeding 150 litres (5.3 cu ft) but not more than 3,000 litres (110 cu ft);[13] Often mounted horizontally in manifolded groups on a trailer or intermodal container frame.
words.name: tube

words.def: Transfer Under Pressure: Transfer of personnel between hyperbaric environments, usually between a closed bell and a saturation system, or between a portable recompression chamber and a multi-occupant chamber
words.name: TUP

words.def:
Main article: Turbidity
The cloudiness or haziness of a fluid caused by individual particles (suspended solids) that may be invisible to the naked eye, similar to smoke in air
words.name: turbidity

words.def: Start the return on a dive which has reached the planned turning point in terms of depth, time, gas supply or distance.[5]
words.name: turn the dive

words.def: Deeper than 60m in the sea, or the part of a cave or cavern that has dim but discernible ambient light.
words.name: twilight zone

words.def:
Main article: Diving bell § Type 1 wet bell
Wet diving bell (q.v.) with no direct supply of gas and services to the bell. Diver umbilicals lead directly to the surface control point.
words.name: type 1 wet bell

words.def:
Main article: Diving bell § Type 2 wet bell
Wet diving bell (q.v.) with umbilical supply of gas and other services to the bell, from which they are distributed to the divers umbilicals from a control panel in the bell.
words.name: type 2 wet bell

words.def: Underwater Breathing Apparatus: Equipment used to supply breathing gas to an underwater diver. Usually refers to the part of the system carried underwater by the diver.
words.name: UBA

words.def: Undersea and Hyperbaric Medical Society
words.name: UHMS

words.def:
Further information: Umbilical cable § Diver
Life support connection to a surface supplied diver or diving bell. Comprises gas supply hoses, a strength member and communications cable, and may also include gas reclaim hose, hot water hose and hoses for hydraulic or pneumatic power, and electrical and optical cables for ancillary equipment. Also refers to the power, control and instrument cable for a ROV.
words.name: umbilical

words.def:
Main article: Undertow (wave action)
A subsurface flow of water returning seaward from shore as result of wave action
words.name: undertow

words.def:
also Jersey upline
A fairly substantial natural fibre rope which is deployed from the bottom using a small lift bag to provide the equivalent of a shotline. The lower end is tied off to the bottom, usually on a wreck, and the diver ascends on the line to avoid being swept away from the site by currents. After reaching the surface, the last diver cuts the line and it sinks back down, Natural fibre is used so the line rots away over a few years.[59]
words.name: upline

words.def: Against the flow.
words.name: upstream

words.def:
Further information: Diving regulator § Upstream vs downstream
Valve, (usually regulator first stage or demand valve), where the valve mechanism moves against the flow when opening, and the pressure difference over the valve tends to close it.
words.name: upstream valve

words.def:
Main article: Upwelling
An oceanographic phenomenon that involves wind-driven motion of dense, cooler, and usually nutrient-rich water towards the ocean surface, replacing the warmer, usually nutrient-depleted surface water
words.name: upwelling

words.def:
Main article: Valsalva maneuver
Technique for equalising the middle ear by moderately forceful attempted exhalation against a closed mouth and blocked nose
words.name: Valsalva maneuver

words.def: structure or frame fitted to scuba cylinder to protect the cylinder valve or manifold and regulator first stage from impact damage and roll-off.
words.name: valve cage

words.def: Safety exercise in which the diver shuts down, tests regulators and re-opens the manifold valves on a twin set in a specific order.
words.name: valve drill

words.def: protective structure or frame fitted to the top of a bulk storage cylinder to protect the cylinder valve from mechanical damage.[13]
words.name: valve guard

words.def:
Main article: Van der Waals equation
Thermodynamic equation of state for a real (non-ideal) gas.
words.name: Van der Waals equation

words.def:
Main article: Vasoconstriction
The narrowing of blood vessels resulting from contraction of the muscular wall of the vessels, particularly the large arteries and small arterioles.
words.name: vasoconstriction

words.def:
Main article: Vasodilation
The widening of blood vessels resulting from relaxation of smooth muscle cells within the vessel walls, particularly in the large veins, large arteries, and smaller arterioles.
words.name: vasodilation

words.def:
Main article: Vertigo
A type of dizziness, where there is a feeling of motion when one is stationary.
words.name: vertigo

words.def:
see also Decompression (diving)#Bubble formation, growth and elimination
Venous gas emboli
words.name: VGE

words.def: 1.  Glass or plastic window on a diving helmet or full face mask.
words.name: viewport

words.def: Visual Inspection Programme (US). Annual visual internal inspection of a scuba cylinder.
words.name: VIP

words.def: Gap between guidelines which is small enough that each line can be seen from the other.[5]
words.name: visual gap

words.def: The procedure of crossing a visual gap (q.v.) without the use of a jump line.[5]
words.name: visual jump

words.def: Internal and external inspection of a pressure vessel as part of revalidation procedure[13]
words.name: visual inspection

words.def: Eddy current test (q.v.) of parallel neck threads of aluminium cylinders
words.name: Visual Plus

words.def:
Main article: Viton
Synthetic elastomer suitable for oxygen service O-rings.
words.name: Viton

words.def:
Main article: Varying Permeability Model
(also Variable permeability model). A decompression model and associated algorithms based on bubble dynamics.
words.name: VPM

words.def:
Main article: Thalmann algorithm
The Exponential/linear decompression algorithm used in the 2008 US Navy decompression tables
words.name: VVAL18

words.def:
Main article: Wall diving
Diving along the face of a near vertical cliff wall, particularly if the bottom is below the range of the diver's equipment and certification. This requires good buoyancy control.
words.name: wall diving

words.def: Of a cylinder: The internal volume. The amount of water it would hold at ambient pressure at 20 °C (68 °F)[13]
words.name: water capacity

words.def: Mechanism to trap liquid water carried by the compressed gas
words.name: water trap

words.def:
Main article: Diving weighting system
Weights, generally made of lead, to counteract the buoyancy of other diving equipment, and the belts, pockets or harnesses used to support them.
words.name: weighting system

words.def: Cover for the viewport area of a helmet or mask to filter excessive light and UV when welding or oxy-arc cutting.
words.name: welding shield

words.def:
Main article: Wellhead
The component at the surface of an oil or gas well that provides the structural and pressure-containing interface for the drilling and production equipment.
words.name: wellhead

words.def:
Further information: Diving bell § Structure of a typical wet bell
A cable-suspended chamber, open at the bottom, that is lowered underwater to operate as a base or a means of transport for a small number of divers.
words.name: wet bell

words.def: Filling scuba cylinders using a water bath for cooling the cylinders.[26]
words.name: wet filling

words.def: Water filled hyperbaric chamber.
words.name: wet pot

words.def: A small notebook of waterproof paper carried by some divers[60]
words.name: wet notes

words.def:
Main article: Wet suit
A close fitting, thermally-insulating, foam neoprene diving suit that allows a limited volume and movement of water inside the suit.
words.name: wet suit

words.def: Flexible high pressure gas hose with connector at the free end, used for temporary connections. e.g. Filling whip, for filling cylinders, Oxygen whip for oxygen transfer, Blending whip, for decanting gases when blending gas, etc.[6]
words.name: whip

words.def: A cable or webbing strap connecting a hose end to the attachment point in addition to the hose end fitting, which restrains the movement of the hose if the connection is broken under pressure. Whip checks connecting two hose ends may also be attached to an anchor point to limit motion further if this is practicable.[61]
words.name: whip check

words.def:
also containment grip[62]
Whip check device which contains a short section of the whip within a braided tube which reduces wear and point loading on the hose, and constrains motion of the hose end more than a standard whip check in case of disconnection under pressure[63]
words.name: whip sock

words.def:
Main article: Backplate and wing
Back inflation buoyancy compensator cell.
words.name: wing

words.def: Woodville Karst Plain Project
words.name: WKPP

words.def: Maximum filling pressure rating for the cylinder at standard temperature. (also Charging pressure)[13]
words.name: working pressure

words.def:
also WOB
Main article: Breathing performance of regulators
The effort expended in inhaling and exhaling the breathing gas.
words.name: work of breathing

words.def:
Main article: Wreck diving
Recreational or technical diving on and inside of shipwrecks.
words.name: wreck diving

words.def: A small plastic writing surface attached to the diver's wrist
words.name: wrist slate

words.def: A fitting used to connect a regulator or filling whip with a DIN thread connection to an international connection cylinder valve.
words.name: yoke adaptor

words.def: A fitting or valve used to connect a regulator or filling whip to a diving cylinder using the "international" connection.[1]
words.name: yoke fitting/valve

words.def:
Further information: Diving cylinder § Plain valves
Cylinder valve body with two outlets and two valve mechanisms which can be independently controlled so that two regulator first stages can be fitted. Similar to H-valve but in Y configuration. Also known as Slingshot valve.
words.name: Y-valve

words.def: Buhlmann decompression algorithms. Also ZHL-16a, b and c
words.name: ZHL-16

words.def:
Main article: Cable tie
(also cable tie, tie wrap) Self-locking plastic strip used to connect objects together.
words.name: zip tie

words.def: Line cutting tool with a replaceable blade in a slot.
words.name: Z-knife
